commit_message:
Fixing Nameless Volume Display

When a volume has no name, it now shows the
ID instead. I also added a fixture data that
represents such a volume being in the system.

Fixes bug #1012380

You can also now use truncate=i on DataTable
Columns in order to have the value truncated if
it goes beyond i characters.

On top of this I fixed/made-clearer a bunch of
the tests relating to volumes and instances.
Please do NOT use deepcopy() of fixture data
in tests any more, instead just create a new
fixture for the data you want.

Change-Id: If2f92b5d04b04f08f5cacca03f614fce5ea38702

commit_message:
Invalidate user tokens when a user is disabled

Fixes Bug 997194

Delete valid tokens for a user when they have been disabled

Moved logic to delete tokens into update_user, as this can be called
directly form the REST API.

Also checks if a user is enabled when creating a token from another
token, this helps in cases there the backend didn't support listing of
tokens (and as a result weren't deleted)

Change-Id: Ib5ed73a7873bfa66ef31bf6d0f0322f50e677688

swift/proxy/server.py:70:80: E501 line too long (82 characters)'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-15 22:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-05-16 07:18:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I some cases you're losing information (TRUE_VALUES? for what?), in others you're hiding information and making a line of code harder to read (MINUTE"}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-05-16 07:25:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Your change hides or loses information making the code harder to read. In your constants file you're not providing enough information about *what* is each constant (type of data, units, when is used, etc).

It adds a small benefit if we want to do some refactoring in some cases, but in current state I don't think is worth."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-16 22:50:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm fine with it though the redundant comments are still in there. The readability factor is definitely going to be an opinion. If folks generally decide they don't want it that's fine too, but I prefer this change over the current code."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-05-16 23:10:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I'd prefer the KB, MB, GB constants to either be powers of 10 or be KiB or KIB (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mebibytes).  Not a big deal, mostly a fanatical desire for disambiguation in this one case... hence the "No score".'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-16 23:19:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:11:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

TRUE_VALUES is defined in two places, swift/common/utils.py and swift/common/constants.py.

It should be removed from the first place so there aren't two copies."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:24:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:27:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Unit test failure now:

======================================================================
ERROR: Failure: ImportError (cannot import name TRUE_VALUES)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/nose-1.1.2-py2.6.egg/nose/loader.py", line 390, in loadTestsFromName
    addr.filename, addr.module)

    return self.importFromDir(dir_path, fqname)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/nose-1.1.2-py2.6.egg/nose/importer.py", line 86, in importFromDir
    mod = load_module(part_fqname, fh, filename, desc)
  File "/home/glange/git/swift/test/unit/common/middleware/test_staticweb.py", line 25, in <module>
    from swift.common.middleware import staticweb
  File "/home/glange/git/swift/swift/common/middleware/staticweb.py", line 124, in <module>
    from swift.common.utils import cache_from_env, get_logger, human_readable, \
ImportError: cannot import name TRUE_VALUES'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-21 20:48:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-22 18:49:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

TRUE_VALUES is imported from the wrong place in:

bin/swift-dispersion-report"}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-23 21:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-05-24 09:15:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Just a little unused import that you may want to remove."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-24 17:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-05-29 20:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-06-04 18:09:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like the addition of KIB, MIB, etc. (they're accurate).  However, the same values are being assigned to constants named KB, MB, etc. which is inaccurate.  One KB is 1000 bytes, while one KiB is 1024 bytes.  So assigning the (correct) value of KIB to KB removes all the benefit of introducing the KIB constant.

If you want to be able to use constants for KB (et al) and KiB (et al), the correct values are:
KB = 1000
MB = 1000 * KB
...

KIB = 1024
MIB = 1024 * MIB
...

Again, I'm not being crazy, just pedantic: see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Quantities_of_bytes"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-06-06 19:39:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-06-07 15:30:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

We shouldn't merge this until either that extra copyright is removed (or we figure out that for some reason that's ok)."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-06-11 21:05:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-06-14 19:44:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Restored'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-06-14 19:44:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
swift.common.constants for swift widly used constants

Create a module for swift widly used constants like swift_dir and other.

* Add more comments to swift.common.constants
* Add synonyms for KB (KIB), MB (MIB), GB (GIB)
* Move swift.common.utils.TRUE_VALUES to swift.common.constants.TRUE_VALUES

Change-Id: Iaf9ba05031cf611eb8d518f8057d39fda09dd403

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-14 16:48:54.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure dnsmasq accept rules are preset at startup.

Fix bug 1000853.

This bug reported that after restarting nova-network, the dnsmasq ACCEPT
iptables rules were no longer present, causing instances to lose their
IP addresses.  This patch updates the restart_dhcp() function in the
linux_net driver to ensure these rules are present even if dnsmasq was
already running.  Before this was only done when first starting dnsmasq.

Change-Id: Icfbe6177d4c913c3d7755ca40a71752bcdaa4448
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure dnsmasq accept rules are preset at startup.

Fix bug 1000853.

This bug reported that after restarting nova-network, the dnsmasq ACCEPT
iptables rules were no longer present, causing instances to lose their
IP addresses.  This patch updates the restart_dhcp() function in the
linux_net driver to ensure these rules are present even if dnsmasq was
already running.  Before this was only done when first starting dnsmasq.

Change-Id: Icfbe6177d4c913c3d7755ca40a71752bcdaa4448

commit_message:
Move docs to doc.

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc/source and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: I205e8bb1ddf6dae1d7392b32975319c6a6d98673

commit_message:
Carrying over token expiry time when token chaining

Fixes bug #998185

This commit causes the token expiry time to be maintained when
one token is being created from another

Change-Id: I7b61692a60d9227423b93c267864a5abe939ca33

subject: Tweak for easier, safer subclassing
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-06 21:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-merge/1195/ : SUCCESS

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-07 14:59:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-06-07 15:10:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-06-07 17:11:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-07 17:33:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-merge/1201/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-pep8/1268/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-python26/300/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-python27/297/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4709/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-07 18:16:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

In response to: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8257/2/keystone/identity/backends/sql.py

I like the intention of the change (sharing common code among similar backends), but the problem is that this change, by itself, creates even *more* divergent code within the existing codebase, and doesn't really have much to do with ldap's check_password beyond the name (method signatures and usage patterns are totally different).

Why not make the same type of change to all applicable backends (SQL, KVS & LDAP... then maybe rework PAM?), and document it cohesively?"}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-06-07 19:16:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think you misunderstood my intention. I mentioned the ldap/core.py code only to show that other modules have their password validation logic as a separate method. I never meant to imply that we should share any of that code. The whole idea is to make it safer to create a subclass, where I can override the password validation to suite our needs and leave the 'authenticate' method in base class.  As it stands today, my subclass of sql.identity has to override the entire 'authenticate' method *just* to replace the call to utils.check_password with something else."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-09 16:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Right, that's the "sharing common code" I was referring to. My issue is that you're creating even more divergent code outside the scope of this review.'}, {'account_id': 1298, 'date': '2012-06-10 20:25:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Dolph, I really don't understand your issue. Maybe we can talk by phone to resolve this?"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-13 21:33:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Alright, I've changed my mind a bit :)

I reviewed the authentication code in the various identity backends (SQL, KVS & LDAP, at least) and there's more differences between them than I realized. While I'd still like to see some refactoring take place, this change alone definitely doesn't have the impact I thought it did."}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-06-14 16:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-14 16:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-14 16:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

commit_message:
Tweak for easier, safer subclassing

Implements the "follow up suggestion" in blueprint sql-identiy-pam

Moved the call to utils.check_password call to its own subroutine.
This allows anyone creating a subclass for sql.Identity to just replace
this new 'check_password' method rather than the entire
'authenticate' method. (This is modeled after ldap/core.py which
already does this.) If the logic in 'authenticate' changes, any
derrived classes won't need to be modified.

Updated to make method private.

Change-Id: I1a06596861fd016f63f5f1a5fe8180993f04f4f5

commit_message:
Invalidate user tokens when password is changed

Fixes bug 996595

This commit will cause all valid tokens to be deleted for a user
who's password is changed (implemented for the sql and kvs backends)

Change-Id: I6ad7da8957b7041983a3fc91d9ba9368667d06ac

[{'created': '2012-06-11 21:25:51.000000000', 'message': 'Implements resume_state_on_host_boot for libvirt.

Adds a new virt driver function to help resume guest states
on host boot. This fixes a couple issue with using a reboot
(like we did previously):

 * Using reboot would clear some task states (VERIFY_RESIZE for example)
 * Provides a mechanism for hypervisor specific guest restarts.
   Reboot would not have worked for XenServer for example...
 * Updates libvirt to use a hard reboot (instead of soft)

Fixes LP Bug #985162.

Change-Id: Iaf5aad75ec9b91f44710a18ddaf3a93378573a62
(cherry picked from commit 6548c509f1780a7168f26de6f2045ec7d5768520)
'}]
commit_message:
Implements resume_state_on_host_boot for libvirt.

Adds a new virt driver function to help resume guest states
on host boot. This fixes a couple issue with using a reboot
(like we did previously):

 * Using reboot would clear some task states (VERIFY_RESIZE for example)
 * Provides a mechanism for hypervisor specific guest restarts.
   Reboot would not have worked for XenServer for example...
 * Updates libvirt to use a hard reboot (instead of soft)

Fixes LP Bug #985162.

Change-Id: Iaf5aad75ec9b91f44710a18ddaf3a93378573a62
(cherry picked from commit 6548c509f1780a7168f26de6f2045ec7d5768520)

commit_message:
Fix expired token tests

Fixes bug #983800

The expiration timestamps are expressed in UTC time, so ensure:

 1) The timestamp of the token created by the test is UTC time (i.e.
    utcnow() vs now())

 2) The expiration check in the dummy memcache client properly
    accounts for UTC (i.e. utctimetuple() vs timetuple())

Change-Id: Ie7356456f79ab5a8070a79771bb7d210b1cedd47

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python26/61/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 11:51:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There's some really nice stuff here Eoghan, kudos!

First high level comment I'd have is around the refresh rules stuff ...

The idea is that when we're adding or removing a bunch of rules, we only want to trigger an expensive refresh after the last update.

In that case, I don't see it as purely an implementation detail that needs to be hidden by the abstraction. Indeed, even now, you're leaking it via the refresh_rules parameter.

A reasonable API for this would be something like this:

  def add_rule(self, group, rule, refresh=True):
      ...
      if refresh:
          self.trigger_refresh(group, [rule])

  def remove_rule(self, group, rule, refresh=True):
      ...
      if refresh:
          self.trigger_refresh(group, [rule])

  def trigger_refresh(self, group, rules):
      ...

i.e. if you're doing a single add/remove, just allow the API handle the triggering. If you're doing a batch update and want to defer the expensive refresh until the end, you need to handle it yourself.

An alternative is to add a batch update API and hide the refresh as an implementation detail behind that. Indeed, that would give nicer behaviour with security group rule quotas

 def add_rules(self, context, id, name, rules,
               exception_type, exception_kw):
     count = QUOTAS.count(context, 'security_group_rules', id)
     try:
         QUOTAS.limit_check(context, security_group_rules=count + len(rules))
     ...

     rule_ids = []
     for values in rules:
         rule = self.db.security_group_rule_create(context, values)
         rule_ids.append(rule['id'])

     self.trigger_rules_refresh(context, id=id)
     self.trigger_handler('security_group_rule_create', context,
                          rule_ids)

 def add_rule(self, context, id, name, rule,
              exception_type, exception_kw):
     return self.add_rules(context, id, name, [rule],
                           exception_type, exception_kw)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 12:18:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

The content of these 'values' dicts are a bit obscure for my liking - couldn't we have something like this:

  def new_group_ingress_rule(self, grantee_group_id, protocol, from_port, to_port):
      return self._new_ingress_rule(group_id=grantee_group_id,
                                    protocol=protocol,
                                    from_port=from_port,
                                     to_port=to_port)

  def new_cidr_ingress_rule(self, grantee_cidr, protocol, from_port, to_port):
      return self._new_ingress_rule(cidr=grantee_cidr,
                                    protocol=protocol,
                                    from_port=from_port,
                                    to_port=to_port)

It wouldn't save code, but it would help to explain the contents and semantics of a rule's values dict.

It would also mean we wouldn't have a weird handle_ports() method in the API."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 12:34:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 12:41:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I'm not loving the way we're doing error handling - passing in pre-constructed exceptions or construction types to methods really pollutes the abstraction

Could we make SecurityGroupAPI and abstract base class with e.g.

  class SecurityGroupAPI(base.Base):

      @staticmethod
      def raise_group_already_exists(msg):
          raise NotImplementedError()

      @staticmethod
      def raise_invalid_property(msg):
          raise NotImplementedError()


and have the EC2 and OpenStack subclasses which implement them?

A cleaner option is to have SecurityGroupAPI raise generic exceptions (e.g. SecurityGroupAlreadyExists) and have the upper layers translate those. But that's probably fairly tedious."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 12:52:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 12:55:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-08 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-08 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Abandoned

I think eglynn is away on vacation. Hopefully he brings this back when he returns.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-06-11 19:51:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Restored

commit_message:
Dedupe native and EC2 security group APIs.

Reduce the code duplication in the native openstack and EC2 APIs
related to security groups, by factoring commonality into a new
internal SecurityGroupAPI.

Also fixes bug lp 1005931

Change-Id: Ifb92bf5d0f07d5713818a3eee6175ef03e8c0b7c

commit_message:
Minor re-order of Object Storage install chapter

A minor reordering of some Object Storage install documentation,
aiming to make it flow better.

* Renamed 'Configuring OpenStack Object Storage' to 'OpenStack Object
  Storage Post Installation' and changed filename to match
* Moved Verifying Installation section above additional proxy server
* Moved a comment about kern.log in the common troubleshooting section
* Removed the 'Troubleshooting' section from 'Configuring ...'

fixes bug 791743

Change-Id: Ibff5326965e88a609457e6d88e1be0150b1db246

This patch fixes broken PDF links in the apt and yum install guides.

However, also logged a bug with the number 1013217 so that we find a
way to have different PDF file names for yum and apt outputs.

Change-Id: I446d7008a21179f98593314799c5e691ebb8fb88

commit_message:
Move docs to doc.

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc/source and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: I925e687254bac9e06c2c520f4fc35a083e21c4ca

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-08 16:46:21.000000000', 'message': "Create a utf8 version of the dns_domains table.

The old dns_domains table was encoded in the 'latin1'
charset and has its primary key length set to 512.
This is too long to be a valid pkey in a proper 'utf8' encoded
table and seems to cause a slew of errors like:

1) Dumping a database with mysqldump and trying to import it fails
because this table is latin1 but fkeys to utf8 tables (projects).

2) Trying to alter the old dns_domains table fails with errors
like:
 mysql> ALTER TABLE dns_domains DROP PRIMARY KEY;
 ERROR 1025 (HY000): Error on rename of './nova/#sql-6cf_855'....

This patch creates a new migration that re-creates the dns_domains
table with a shorter 'domain' column which works with the utf8
charset.

Fixes LP Bug #993663.

Change-Id: I2060d39cbdabd20f410ebd501160a04c51641755
"}, {'created': '2012-06-08 17:02:26.000000000', 'message': "Create a utf8 version of the dns_domains table.

charset and has its primary key length set to 512.

table and seems to cause a slew of errors like:

1) Dumping a database with mysqldump and trying to import it fails
because this table is latin1 but fkeys to utf8 tables (projects).

2) Trying to alter the old dns_domains table fails with errors
like:
 mysql> ALTER TABLE dns_domains DROP PRIMARY KEY;
 ERROR 1025 (HY000): Error on rename of './nova/#sql-6cf_855'....

This patch creates a new migration that re-creates the dns_domains

charset.

Fixes LP Bug #993663.

Change-Id: I2060d39cbdabd20f410ebd501160a04c51641755
"}]
commit_message:
Create a utf8 version of the dns_domains table.

The old dns_domains table was encoded in the 'latin1'
charset and has its primary key length set to 512.
This is too long to be a valid pkey in a proper 'utf8' encoded
table and seems to cause a slew of errors like:

1) Dumping a database with mysqldump and trying to import it fails
because this table is latin1 but fkeys to utf8 tables (projects).

2) Trying to alter the old dns_domains table fails with errors
like:
 mysql> ALTER TABLE dns_domains DROP PRIMARY KEY;
 ERROR 1025 (HY000): Error on rename of './nova/#sql-6cf_855'....

This patch creates a new migration that re-creates the dns_domains
table with a shorter 'domain' column which works with the utf8
charset.

Fixes LP Bug #993663.

Change-Id: I2060d39cbdabd20f410ebd501160a04c51641755

commit_message:
API v2: mprove validation of post/put, rename few attributes

bug #1012438

Additional work for bp v2-api-melange-integration

- rename few attributes:
  op_state -> status
  additional_routes -> additional_host_routes
  prefix -> cidr

- expand request body validation to indicate whether fields can be
specified during create and or update.
- add test cases to validate defaults, and input validation.

- update db_base_plugin_v2 to generate gateway_ip for subnet and mac
for port when unspecified.

- validate that tenant-id is only specified in req by admin users

- automatically set tenant-id based on request.context.tenant_id if needed

- enable port tests in test_db_plugin.py

Change-Id: If7f5101e4974a6ef93ff8a1d945f8642dd21b16e

Something is wrong with Jenkins I think...'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-06-08 18:23:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-06-11 01:26:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I suppose it's inevitable that we need something like this... I *really* prefer not to have methods like this floating around though. It gets dreadfully easy to write code that gets run multiple times when it shouldn't and that isn't scoped properly and ends up being applied repeatedly to the same elements inappropriately.

I'll give this a +1 for solving the bug, but I would like to register my ideological preference that we favor delegated event handlers and live selectors whenever possible. Any solution other than re-running a chunk of code every time is preferable to me.

Just to be clear, this isn't a comment on any problems with this code (which seems well-written to me)."}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-06-11 07:20:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Gabriel, I was in a similar doubt... I've worked on two different solutions, and will soon upload the second one, I'd be glad to hear your opinion on it too."}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-06-11 09:56:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-06-11 09:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-06-11 10:00:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Changes in the latest patch set:

1. Added a <div class="modal_wrapper"> in the base template, to serve as a modal wrapper. Now all live event delegates can be attached to it.
2. Improved selectors - instead of attaching live delegates to 'document' and 'body', now more specific elements are used.
3. The table processing functions are added on the modal.shown event, with passing the 'parent' field to process, instead of crawling the whole document again.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-11 10:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Common table functions are now run on modal.show

When a modal windows is displayed, a set of
functions need to be executed, to perform
some additional processing on the tables
in the modal like check-all checkbox,
table sorting, etc.

Fixes bug 997670

Change-Id: I1fdd2d55ccaa184d5fb34e4c0fed7455dee6b0d3

commit_message:
Fix pep8 issues.

Fix several pep8 issues and pin the pep8 test to pep8 version 1.1.
This should prevent future changes from being unmergable by the pep8
gate after a pep8 upgrade.

Change-Id: I4678a9179579fb5c7afe795fb43a8a89a99ad717

commit_message:
Fix multiple distro dependency bug

get_packages() icorrectly handled multiple distros listed in a dependency
file, such as:

    xyz  # dist:fred,barney,wilma

Change-Id: Ib1178b2aaaddafe581902b32776180bb0b41f1ae

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-11 21:20:16.000000000', 'message': 'Update default policies for KVM guest PIT & RTC timers

The default policies for the KVM guest PIT and RTC timers
are not very good at maintaining reliable time in guest
operating systems. In particular Windows 7 guests will
often crash with the default KVM timer policies, and old
Linux guests will have very bad time drift

Set the PIT such that missed ticks are injected at the
normal rate, ie they are delayed

Set the RTC such that missed ticks are injected at a
higher rate to "catch up"

This corresponds to the following libvirt XML

  <clock offset='utc'>
    <timer name='pit' tickpolicy='delay'/>
    <timer name='rtc' tickpolicy='catchup'/>
  </clock>

And the following KVM options

  -no-kvm-pit-reinjection
  -rtc base=utc,driftfix=slew

This should provide a default configuration that works
acceptably for most OS types. In the future this will
likely need to be made configurable per-guest OS type.

Fixes bug 1011848

Change-Id: Iafb0e2192b5f3c05b6395ffdfa14f86a98ce3d1f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2012-06-12 10:46:46.000000000', 'message': 'Update default policies for KVM guest PIT & RTC timers

The default policies for the KVM guest PIT and RTC timers
are not very good at maintaining reliable time in guest
operating systems. In particular Windows 7 guests will
often crash with the default KVM timer policies, and old
Linux guests will have very bad time drift

Set the PIT such that missed ticks are injected at the
normal rate, ie they are delayed

Set the RTC such that missed ticks are injected at a
higher rate to "catch up"

This corresponds to the following libvirt XML

  <clock offset='utc'>
    <timer name='pit' tickpolicy='delay'/>
    <timer name='rtc' tickpolicy='catchup'/>
  </clock>

And the following KVM options

  -no-kvm-pit-reinjection
  -rtc base=utc,driftfix=slew

This should provide a default configuration that works
acceptably for most OS types. In the future this will
likely need to be made configurable per-guest OS type.

Fixes LP bug #1011848

Change-Id: Iafb0e2192b5f3c05b6395ffdfa14f86a98ce3d1f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Update default policies for KVM guest PIT & RTC timers

The default policies for the KVM guest PIT and RTC timers
are not very good at maintaining reliable time in guest
operating systems. In particular Windows 7 guests will
often crash with the default KVM timer policies, and old
Linux guests will have very bad time drift

Set the PIT such that missed ticks are injected at the
normal rate, ie they are delayed

Set the RTC such that missed ticks are injected at a
higher rate to "catch up"

This corresponds to the following libvirt XML

  <clock offset='utc'>
    <timer name='pit' tickpolicy='delay'/>
    <timer name='rtc' tickpolicy='catchup'/>
  </clock>

And the following KVM options

  -no-kvm-pit-reinjection
  -rtc base=utc,driftfix=slew

This should provide a default configuration that works
acceptably for most OS types. In the future this will
likely need to be made configurable per-guest OS type.

Fixes LP bug #1011848

Change-Id: Iafb0e2192b5f3c05b6395ffdfa14f86a98ce3d1f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add support for configuring libvirt VM clock and timers

There are a number of time sources made available to guests,
each of which have a number of configurable policies. This
introduces config APIs for the libvirt domain XML to configure
the clock time sources

Change-Id: Ic5047b02b4753f20bb9a63e85130d84258df7a28
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix bug 988034 - Quantum Network Manager - not clearing ips

Added a line in nova_ipam_lib.QuantumNovaIPAMLib init
method to ensure we clean up IPs and explanation of whats
going on.

Also, nuked release_fixed_ip as that is not
needed in QuantumManager anymore.

Change-Id: I3971b4d4c464ce68ba9370c9f5d8ca7840e0a72a

commit_message:
Move docs to doc.

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: Ic523a716e4113198b777d6dc3db8bb8a729e7696

commit_message:
Support revisions in version numbers

Introduce REVISION in versioning scheme, in order to support future
stable versioning (2012.2.x).

Change-Id: I3015cfbf3938c4994bbda8d63fdbd346b7535a6b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-01 13:32:24.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint lvm-disk-images

Add ability to use LVM volumes for VM disks.

Implements LVM disks support for libvirt driver.

VM disks will be stored on sparse LVM volumes in volume group
 specified by `libvirt_images_volume_group` option.
 Another option `libvirt_local_images_type` specify which storage
 type will be used. Supported values are `raw`, `lvm`, `qcow2`,
 `legacy`. `legacy`is default option value. In this case, usual
 logic with `use_cow_images` flag is used.
Commit introduce three classes: `Raw`, `Qcow2` and `Lvm`. They contain
 image creation logic, that was stored in
 `LibvirtConnection._cache_image` and `libvirt_info` methods,
 that produce right `LibvirtGuestConfigDisk` configurations for
 libvirt. `Backend` class choose which image type to use.

Change-Id: I0d01cb7d2fd67de2565b8d45d34f7846ad4112c2

Add ability to use LVM volumes for VM disks.

Implements LVM disks support for libvirt driver.

VM disks will be stored on LVM volumes in volume group
 specified by `libvirt_images_volume_group` option.
 Another option `libvirt_local_images_type` specify which storage
 type will be used. Supported values are `raw`, `lvm`, `qcow2`,
 `default`. If `libvirt_local_images_type` = `default`, usual
 logic with `use_cow_images` flag is used.
Boolean option `libvirt_sparse_logical_volumes` controls which type
 of logical volumes will be created (sparsed with virtualsize or
 usual logical volumes with full space allocation). Default value
 for this option is `False`.
Commit introduce three classes: `Raw`, `Qcow2` and `Lvm`. They contain
 image creation logic, that was stored in
 `LibvirtConnection._cache_image` and `libvirt_info` methods,
 that produce right `LibvirtGuestConfigDisk` configurations for
 libvirt. `Backend` class choose which image type to use.

Change-Id: I0d01cb7d2fd67de2565b8d45d34f7846ad4112c2

 type will be used. Supported values are `raw`, `lvm`, `qcow2`,
 `default`. If `libvirt_local_images_type` = `default`, usual
 logic with `use_cow_images` flag is used.
Boolean option `libvirt_sparse_logical_volumes` controls which type
 of logical volumes will be created (sparsed with virtualsize or
 usual logical volumes with full space allocation). Default value
 for this option is `False`.
Commit introduce three classes: `Raw`, `Qcow2` and `Lvm`. They contain
 image creation logic, that was stored in
 `LibvirtConnection._cache_image` and `libvirt_info` methods,
 that produce right `LibvirtGuestConfigDisk` configurations for
 libvirt. `Backend` class choose which image type to use.

Change-Id: I0d01cb7d2fd67de2565b8d45d34f7846ad4112c2

commit_message:
blueprint lvm-disk-images

Add ability to use LVM volumes for VM disks.

Implements LVM disks support for libvirt driver.

VM disks will be stored on LVM volumes in volume group
 specified by `libvirt_images_volume_group` option.
 Another option `libvirt_local_images_type` specify which storage
 type will be used. Supported values are `raw`, `lvm`, `qcow2`,
 `default`. If `libvirt_local_images_type` = `default`, usual
 logic with `use_cow_images` flag is used.
Boolean option `libvirt_sparse_logical_volumes` controls which type
 of logical volumes will be created (sparsed with virtualsize or
 usual logical volumes with full space allocation). Default value
 for this option is `False`.
Commit introduce three classes: `Raw`, `Qcow2` and `Lvm`. They contain
 image creation logic, that was stored in
 `LibvirtConnection._cache_image` and `libvirt_info` methods,
 that produce right `LibvirtGuestConfigDisk` configurations for
 libvirt. `Backend` class choose which image type to use.

Change-Id: I0d01cb7d2fd67de2565b8d45d34f7846ad4112c2

commit_message:
Log connection_type deprecation message as WARNING

Updates the connection_type log messages to log as
a warning instead of an error.

Fixes LP Bug #1011788.

Change-Id: I4cc2d9d5fdea2c8871f760b73a905fe61edcbe8f

Before this is removed, I'd appreciate comments on the mailing list thread around this, because we actually have need of a standard way to do deprecation."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-06-13 17:27:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think the original approach to deprecation here was a little misguided. Logging deprecation is going to communicate to deployers, not developers. So it makes a ton of sense to add deprecation warnings to logs for things deployers can control, like configuration settings. But it doesn't make as much sense to me for classes or methods. That kind of code structure deprecation is something more geared towards developers, and we openstack developers have better mechanisms such as the mailing list and blueprints for communicating such concerns.

Will cross-post this to the ML for more discussion."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-13 18:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

My vote is for simplicity.  +1 to removal.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-13 18:49:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Remove utils.deprecated functions.

We don't seem to use utils.deprecated at all... so lets
remove it and save ourselves 200 lines of code.

Also moves a couple misc. test cases in utils.py out of the
DeprecationTest suite and into the GenericUtilsTestCase
suite.

Change-Id: I03f71f2ee06a526a8902a3079257afd6fd65dc59

commit_message:
Import db driver through configuration

Using the 'data_api' config option, a deployer can now define
which module to be used as the db driver.

Related to bp refactor-db-layer

Change-Id: Ie93b7331e5f8f3456b682d974ac6fd2cdb1e53b7

commit_message:
Improved message handling.

  * Login page no longer displays user messages
    inappropriately. Instead, login errors are handled
    as form errors. Fixes bug 1012467.
  * Messages triggered during an AJAX call are no longer
    added to the standard message queue (which causes
    them to appear on subsequent unrelated requests).
    Instead, they are encoded and sent back with the AJAX
    response, allowing them to be displayed to the user
    client-side when they are relevant.
    Fixes bug 1008799.
  * Adds the last couple "compress" tags to the
    _scripts.html template to completely implement
    blueprint asset-compression.

Change-Id: I967f32b44603ded7ec95bd0b86e7d997c6a8b352

commit_message:
Move RequestContext.is_image_* methods to db layer

These methods need direct access to the db and therefore require
the request context module to maintain a connection to the database.
Moving them to the db layer allows us to further refactor the
db layer.

This does duplicate the methods in each of the db drivers, so a
future patch is needed to simplify that.

Related to bp refactor-db-layer

Change-Id: Ia7e0dbb9f2162fb69837699b970f8cab3efcd545

subject: Use zipballs instead of git urls.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:39:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/785/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/967/ : SUCCESS

"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:56:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:57:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Not a big fan of using zipball's. I've tried using zipball/tarball's from GitHub before and had issues with them getting out of sync with the Git Repo's.

As near as I can tell these get refreshed as a background task and won't always be up to date."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:59:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Dan:

In the way we are using them, I think getting a zipball a commit behind is fine. What are you specifically worried about here?'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:15:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:19:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

So, until we have real releases to pypi of client libs (coming real soon now) there isn't really another good choice because python is a pile of steaming turds.

distutils is the thing used by setup.py install. Although we have pip-requires parsing injected into our setup.py files, _it_ does not understand git urls.

So if you are pip installing, you're fine, because pip does an egg_info, then installs the deps, then installs your package via setup.py install, which works around distutils being broken. But if you are just trying to install from source (or do a python setup.py develop) everything turns to crap.

We should have everything uploading to pypi within the next week though, so hopefully this will remain temporary.

Also - a specific sha1 tagged zipball can't really get out of date with anything."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:21:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

If this is the best we can do I suppose it is Okay for a short term solution.

Just wanted to point out that I've had issues with them in the past. In any case I won't hold this up if it is what we need to do."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-13 17:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-13 17:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-13 18:27:04.000000000', 'message': "Work around hpcloud hostname issue.

The hostname needs to be in /etc/hosts, we can't rely on
the dns server that hpcloud is using now; it breaks during
nova network reconfiguration, and that breaks sudo.

Change-Id: I4f0a39f5d629f1eeaf47af66528db3c63692810b
"}]
commit_message:
Work around hpcloud hostname issue.

The hostname needs to be in /etc/hosts, we can't rely on
the dns server that hpcloud is using now; it breaks during
nova network reconfiguration, and that breaks sudo.

Change-Id: I4f0a39f5d629f1eeaf47af66528db3c63692810b

subject: Fix to not use deprecated response.environ any more.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1801, 'name': 'Duncan McGreggor', 'email': 'duncan.mcgreggor@rackspace.com', 'username': 'oubiwann'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-08 17:56:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

FYI, this wasn't caught in the unit tests because of this bug:
  https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1010579"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-08 17:59:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-08 18:14:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/748/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/930/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/439/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/441/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4825/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-08 22:41:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is this backwards-compatibile with the 1.x release?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-08 22:42:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Additionally, I'd like to see this fix done in a more common place than the v1 images controller. Can you look into fixing it in glance.common.wsgi:Resource.__call__ (or whichever method makes sense)?"}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-08 22:55:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, this is compatible with 1.x WebOb. (in as much as everything that's in the current codebase is). Take a look at the logic check; the new code path is followed only if the value of the request.response.environ is None; previous versions of WebOb set that automatically (this is no longer done; one has to set that value if one wants to use it)."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-11 14:17:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok, good point :)

I'd still like to see this done in a more common place."}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-11 14:35:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, totally -- thanks for the tip; it's a good idea. I hope to have time to get back to this sometime today."}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-11 17:13:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Okay, so I took some time to poke around in the code. 

Unfortunately, the wsgi.Resource object is not used by the ImageSerializer class, but instead wsgi.JSONResponseSerializer is. That class doesn't have the __call__ method, and some quick checks revealed that updating its default method didn't work.

I don't have the time right now to find out how wsgi.JSONResponseSerializer works and what methods would be necessary to override in order to tweak such that the response gets the expected .environ attr.

I'll look into this some more when I have the time to trace out the code path followed when ImageSerializer.show is called."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-11 17:31:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Would you prefer I take the work you have done and try to apply it in the proper place? I've got a lot of time to commit to things like this :)"}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-11 17:51:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think I've got a solution in place. Let me know what you think about it:

I did take another look (it's so hard to leave these things just sitting there... staring at you...) and there is no method that's upcalled anywhere for the serializer code.

As such, my thought is this:

to actually create a decorator that gets executed by everything needing to access the response. Or, to provide a more optimized solution -- and one that addresses this particular issue -- a decorator that is used for any method that expects to access the response.environ attribute, and then make sure that the .environ attr is actually present.

What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-11 18:01:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Alternatively, and more simply, don't use the WebOb Response.environ attr at all. That was originally just copied from Response.request.environ anyway, so we might as well update to use something that's always been there and is not discouraged.

A simple grep through the code reveals this to potentially be the obvious solution:

$ git grep environ|grep response
glance/api/v1/images.py:            if 'eventlet.posthooks' in response.environ:
glance/api/v1/images.py:                response.environ['eventlet.posthooks'].append(
glance/tests/unit/v1/test_api.py:        response.environ['eventlet.posthooks'] = []
glance/tests/unit/v1/test_api.py:        self.assertNotEqual(response.environ['eventlet.posthooks'], [])"}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-11 18:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-11 18:24:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Okay, I've submitted a new patch that removes the old response.environ reference in favor of the even older and currently supported attr reference: response.request.environ."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-06-11 18:28:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-11 18:37:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/767/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/949/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/458/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/460/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4942/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-11 20:22:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-11 23:19:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm fine with this. Is the 'environ' attribute documented anywhere? I couldn't find it in the official Request API reference."}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-13 14:58:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hey Brian,

Mark's the guy that had experience with this in the past, so I asked him :-) He pointed to this location:
  http://docs.webob.org/en/latest/news.html

In particular, if you scroll down to the 1.2b1 release notes, you'll see:

"""
Response.request and Response.environ attrs are undeprecated and no longer raise exceptions when used. These can also be passed to the Response constructor. This is to support codebases that pass them to the constructor or assign them to a response instance. However, some behavior differences from 1.1 exist. In particular, synchronization is no longer done between environ and request attribute properties of Response; you may pass either to the constructor (or both) or assign one or the other or both, but they wont be managed specially and will remain the same over the lifetime of the response just as you passed them. Default values for both request and environ on any given response are None now.
"""

If you scroll down further to the 1.1.1 release notes, you'll see:

"""
Deprecate Response.request and Response.environ attrs.
"""'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:01:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I found that documentation, too, I was more interested in where 'Request.environ' is documented. I couldn't seem to find that anywhere."}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:09:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ah, well if you found that, then you've probably seen this:
  http://docs.webob.org/en/latest/reference.html

And I think that constitutes the extent of the public, non-code/docsting/comment docs."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:14:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yeah, I did see that, too. I spend a lot of time in those docs :)

And it appears that's the only documentation of Request.environ: nothing that explicitly describes it but a few examples that use it. That sucks. Hopefully they don't deprecate it on us...I wonder if they've done that before...BUT there's nothing you can do about it, this patch looks solid to me. We just need wait on another core approval."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:07:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Request.environ is really a reference to the environ dict passed by the WSGI server when the app is called (webob.dec.wsgify hides this).  WebOb documentation is light on details because the different WSGI servers and deployment configs can add other keys to the environ (see PEP333).'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-06-13 18:12:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-13 18:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/793/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/975/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/484/ : SUCCESS

commit_message:
Fix to not use deprecated response.environ any more.

WebOb 1.2 doesn't auto-set the response environment. There was only one place
in Glance that was using this, so it was changed in favor of the stable API
that has always been there: response.request.environ.

This change fixes bug #1010560.

Change-Id: I2e58bf32970c95d25cad0a35ee38b9540483eef0

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc/source and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: Idf3e4472f91a1f5ae36e64b339bef99d4d960b88
'}]
commit_message:
Edit build_sphinx options.

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc/source and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: Idf3e4472f91a1f5ae36e64b339bef99d4d960b88

commit_message:
Removes NOVACLIENT_DEBUG from client code.

It's OK to do this because only the shell uses the --debug arg. The code that
uses the client code will set the log level appropriately.

Fixes bug 922742.

Change-Id: I9e925f53c17c73f4442121e52811d52603afab29

commit_message:
Begin replacement of sqlalchemy driver imports

Create glance.db:get_api to handle importing the configured data
api module. Currently it's hard-coded to glance.db.sqlalchemy.api.

Related to bp refactor-db-layer

Change-Id: Ie9b078bddf6324bf0e76d562489a6695ed8b88df

commit_message:
Always setup rootwrap sudoers entry

Setup /etc/sudoers.d/nova-rootwrap in all cases, and not just
when devstack is not run as root. Fixes bug 1011652.

Change-Id: Ib4cdeaa282f01cf2ce98119618f232c91b6e8db4

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-13 04:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Not sure if this is the thing to do to get a new version released with a bugfix, but 1.5.0 has an error in it where some things (like 404s) can result in 500s instead.

This review was made by:

git checkout -b milestone-proposed 1.5.0
# Apply patch and commit it
git review milestone-proposed

Feel free to do whatever really needs to be done with this or let me know what I should do. :)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-13 07:24:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Milestone-proposed is an ephemeral pre-release branch, not a long-running stable/* branch so that's probably not the right place for this (milestone-proposed for 1.5.0 should actually have been deleted already). Let me check what our options are with mtaylor before accepting that one."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:08:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

We'll get this sorted out and resubmit. The one for master is still valid though."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-13 04:00:46.000000000', 'message': "Make proxy-logging more like eventlet.posthook

The old use of Eventlet's posthook process meant that responses that
forgot to include content-length or transfer-encoding headers would
get one tacked on, if Eventlet could guess what was probably meant. I
added a bit of that logic into proxy-logging now as we saw some
errors resulting from this.

Change-Id: I7d1a715914f7b350eb6d9345f36fda7635f84d85
"}]
commit_message:
Make proxy-logging more like eventlet.posthook

The old use of Eventlet's posthook process meant that responses that
forgot to include content-length or transfer-encoding headers would
get one tacked on, if Eventlet could guess what was probably meant. I
added a bit of that logic into proxy-logging now as we saw some
errors resulting from this.

Change-Id: I7d1a715914f7b350eb6d9345f36fda7635f84d85

Step 1 of refactoring compute tests

* Fix all imports to align with HACKING standards

this library.

Changed to keep 2.4 compatibility

commit_message:
Update swift-get-nodes to return fewer more_nodes

Changed swift-get-nodes to just return up to replica_count of
more_nodes instead of all of them. When you have thousands of drives,
returning all possible handoff nodes is pretty crazy. :)

Change-Id: I864e7243726ca3ef2ac08c4ab660a05789f37878

commit_message:
Add build_sphinx options.

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: I672fbd296e2b8f1da1eede74d6f0c7a26345cf74

subject: More predictable S3 image ID generation.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 12:50:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 13:58:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-10 14:33:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

You need to file a blueprint for this. I also don't quite understand the benefit...why do images need to have predictable image ids?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 15:12:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 15:15:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Brian,

I've raised a blueprint as requested:

  https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/predictable-s3-image-id

The idea is to facilitate glance image replication, as discussed on the ML:

  https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg11182.html

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-10 16:00:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thanks for the info, Eoghan. I'm not sure it really makes sense to implement a solution that has collisions. It *might* be fine for small deployments, but what about the large cloud providers that are easily going to have 80k users. I dont' think it's acceptable to say some of those users can't use snapshots, right?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 16:29:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Brian,

I don't understand the snapshot issue - can you explain?

There's a simple collision handling strategy implemented in:

 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7302/4/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py

so in the case of these infrequent collisions, an s3_image ID is still generated and we're no worse a position that the current situation that pertains for all images.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-10 16:46:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thinking about this more, I see two major issues:

1) If you are generating images at a high rate (i.e. snapshots in a large deployment) then you have to assume there will be collisions. When there are collisions, you lose the predictability. Additionally, if a user creates a snapshot that conflicts with an existing id, the user will want to predict what that id but will end up using the wrong image.

2) We can't guarantee two images that are replicated between nodes don't conflict before said replication. If you have two glance nodes that independently generate images before you try to replicate those images between the nodes, if the ids conflict then the collisions will be handled differently on each node. To give a concrete example, if you generate image AA on both glance1 and glance2, then replicate, the image from glance1 will be called AB on glance2, while the image from glance2 will be called AB on glance1."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 16:49:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 16:51:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Patch set 5 fixes migration script index collision with another patch merged in the meantime - this should resolve the failures reported by smokestack on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 17:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Brian,

Sure, such occurrences are indeed possible (with low probability) - this is an unavoidable side-effect of the relative size of the domain and range.

The point though is to make an incremental improvement in terms of the amount of retrospective fix-up required by an inter-region image replication tool.

With the current approach to generating s3 image IDs, almost all IDs from the source region are likely to be invalid in the destination region.

With this change, the opposite is the case - almost all  (new) images will map to the same s3 image ID in both. This would mean that the replication tool only needs to potentially have special-case handling for a relative handful of IDs.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-10 17:21:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I understand the benefits, I'm just weary of accepting a partial solution to the problem. Many people will accept this as *the* solution then be flabbergasted when they get their first collision. I'm not blocking this from going in, I just want to make sure we all understand what's going on here. I'd like to hear from some other people on this issue before the approach is accepted."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-10 18:55:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Now that I see this in more detail I'm unconvinced that this is actually the right way to go. It doesn't seem like we can ever get to the point where people can reliably convert externally from uuid to ec2/s3, so what is the point in giving the impression that they can?

I think we need to figure out what is the right long term way of doing this because I'm not sure that this actually gets us any closer.  One possibility would be to hand out unique ids from a central location and store them in metadata on the actual objects."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-10 19:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Vish,

Sure the proposed mapping isn't perfect, but the thought was to minimize the scope of the required ID post-replication fix-ups to the relatively rare colliding IDs as opposed to every single ID.

My gut feeling is that a central ID-issuing authority would be overkill in this case, and would go against the spirit of the distributed quasi-uniqueness given by the UUID scheme. 

Here's another idea, suppose we reserve a slice at the top of the ID space to accommodate collisions, so that its immediately apparent to a replication tool that an ID is "tainted" and would require a manual fix-up after image replication occurs.

So the UUID-to-ID mapping could obviously collide in the source region, or the destination region (or both). For unreplicated images it wouldn't make a difference, but when the replication tool sees a ID from the reserved range in the source or destination, it could mark the replicated image in some way to indicate that the old S3 image ID wouldn't apply in the destination region.

Do you see any value in that kind of approach?

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-11 10:40:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Vish/Brian,

One final idea on this that came up in an IRC discussion, the gist being ...

If we could rewind back to when glance changed from integer image IDs to UUIDs, we could ensure for the Amazon image formats {ami, ari, aki} a reduced UUID space was allocated from (i.e. instead of the full 122 bit randomness in the generated UUIDs, we could just have 32 bits of randomness for those image types)

Now if glance were to allocate UUIDs from such a "reduced" domain, this would enable a perfect collision-free mapping going forward.

In a sense, there's a fundamental mismatch between the glance and EC2 ID schemes as things currently stand, though the extra "width" of the glance UUID space is unnecessary in practical terms (i.e. I wouldn't expect a 32-bit range to a limiting constraint, as no practical deployment is likely to have anything close to ~4.3 billion images in use).

Obviously there would be an issue with the existing UUIDs and s3 image IDs out in the wild already. 

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-11 19:08:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The limited UUID approach has a few major drawbacks:

1) If you are limiting everything to a a small space, then you will have collisions in uuids as if they were only 32 bits. You can regenerate until you get a non-conflict, but you still have the problem below.

2) You will still have potential collisions across two glance deploys, so replication will be a problem and you still have to solve conflicts.

3) We currently allow all images to be booted through the amazon api, even whole disk images with no kernel and ramdisk. If we limit the special generation to only amazon-style images, then we lose this feature.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-11 19:28:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Vish,

OK, so if we stick with the insertion-order-dependent S3 image ID mapping, then it seems to me that we'll need to expose a native API extension to allow client map between the glance UUID and the corresponding S3 image ID.

IIUC the current AWSOME proxy logic for RunInstances for example, it's expecting the client to pass in the glance UUID directly instead of the normal ami-* style ID generally used with EC2 client tooling. Reading between the lines, this seems due to the lack of any external visibility to the ID mapping as maintained by the s3_images table.

Is it likely that such an API extension would be accepted upstream?

/Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-11 20:08:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Or I guess if we were willing to pollute the native API's image metadata with the S3 image ID, that would be simpler than adding a new API extension to map between the image ID forms. 

However the more pure option would be to keep the native API image representation free of any EC2-specifics.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-14 11:01:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-14 11:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Yet another case of the latest sqlalchemy migration script index being taken by another merge.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-14 15:10:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'm sure I'm just misunderstanding how this works, but shouldn't there be a nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py update that accompanies this change?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-14 16:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-14 16:16:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@markwash

Good catch, the id column type is now updated in nova.db.sqlalchemy.models:S3Image

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-23 13:12:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I really don't want to let this fall off everyone's radars, would it make sense to schedule a time on IRC to discuss how we can move forward? There is definitely a problem to solve here, but we need to come up with what we all agree is the right solution. Eoghan?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-24 08:45:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Cool, lets discuss on IRC. 

I'm away from the office today, how about tomorrow afternoon GMT / morning PST?
 
Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-29 14:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

For the record, IRC discussion here:

  http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-dev/%23openstack-dev.2012-05-25.log'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-29 20:56:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Do you want to abandon this review?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-13 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-13 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
More predictable S3 image ID generation.

Implements bp predictable-s3-image-id

Instead of the generated key into the s3_images table being totally
dependent on an on-demand insertion order, we now generate the S3
image ID from the underlying glance image UUID so that the mapping
is predictable (modulo collisions).

Since the domain space is much wider than the range (122 unique bit
UUID versus a 32-bit ami ID), collisions are inevitable - in testing
the first colliding ID tends to occur after 75-80k image UUIDs have
been generated.

Change-Id: I0e07b8a94bc356728246f3a94bc336ccea73129b

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-12 17:34:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not merge

I'm not sure I understand the value of this. What value is the openstack.common.jsonutils module adding?"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-12 22:14:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Brian,
The benefit I think jsonutils offers is the consistent serialization of objects across OpenStack projects provided by the "to_primitive" method (which is in the jsonutils module).'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-12 22:29:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

That is a good point, but to_primitive was designed to encode dictionaries for internal rpc communication. The only thing that this could get us is automatic encoding of datetime objects - however, it doesn't encode them properly for Glance's purposes. We depend on encoding into ISO8601, not datetime.datetime's default __str__ method. So as far as I can tell we will just be doing more work with this and it isn't going to add any real value..."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-12 22:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Glance should use openstack.common.jsonutils

Implements blueprint use-common-jsonutils

1. Edit openstack-common.conf and import glance/openstack/common/jsonutils.py
2. Remove json package imports and replace with jsonutils

Change-Id: I72c4a9c4edbf6b0c0f4205aef4acad982b7f5ae0

There is a bit of a complication with impl_zmq worth mentioning.  It
requires a service to run (nova/bin/nova-rpc-zmq-receiver).  Only once
instance of this service should run on a given machine, so it shouldn't
be copied into each project that uses rpc.  Once openstack-common is an
installed library, it can be distributed with that, but until then ...
we'll just leave it in nova for now.

commit_message:
Add impl_zmq to rpc.

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

This driver just went into nova.rpc.  Pull it in over here.  I haven't
been able to test this, but I can't get the tests to work in nova,
either.

There is a bit of a complication with impl_zmq worth mentioning.  It
requires a service to run (nova/bin/nova-rpc-zmq-receiver).  Only once
instance of this service should run on a given machine, so it shouldn't
be copied into each project that uses rpc.  Once openstack-common is an
installed library, it can be distributed with that, but until then ...
we'll just leave it in nova for now.

Change-Id: I2bd067be58d943d4f3a90e013b22282217484872

Fix utcnow_ts to return UTC timestamp

Fixes bug #1011121

Use calendar.timegm instead of time.mktime

Change-Id: Idb8d470f1ef90162641d21122699a026fa38faf1

commit_message:
implement sql-comment-string stack traces

Implements solution for bug 1007648.

Add python stack traces to all sql comment strings so that someone
looking at database query logs can immediately see what code
generated each query. This is especially powerful when combined
with pt-query-digest to get per-file or per-method aggregates.

Change-Id: Ieda5cf4d70cc2643d27fb00efb48de14ca2abe52

commit_message:
Fixed validation check for ICMP rules

Fixed the code that checks the ICMP type/code
as from/to ports. Also fixed the CSS for the
security rules form, and the script to change
the form labels in case of form reload due to
an error.

Fixes bug 997669

Change-Id: I3b9c0ba3f46b91a311f887560dae5e9399961b84

subject: Horizon should use openstack.common.jsonutils
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-07 09:21:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-merge/611/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/771/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python26/37/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python27/37/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4683/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-06-07 18:32:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The code here is fine, but I don't see the benefit to this change. Can you explain what we actually gain by using this code?

As I understand it, this module literally wraps the standard library's json module which we're already using, adding a layer of abstraction to solve a problem that we don't have...

I'm all for aligning with OpenStack, but I'm not in favor of change for change's sake."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-07 20:19:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Actually, that was what I was thinking after realizing there was only few places using the json package. Since other projects are on the move towards openstack-common I just thought Horizon should also.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-11 17:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-11 17:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-merge/645/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/804/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python26/70/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python27/70/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4933/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-06-11 19:30:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm confused by this approach.  I understand that there's value in making use of openstack-common, but copying and pasting files from openstack-common into an individual project is not the best way to do that.

I assumed this would mean adding openstack-common as a dependency of Horizon and importing the code from there.  Can you give any info as to why you chose this approach?"}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-06-11 21:48:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree, this seems like it would cause dependency/versioning issues. Is there a way to make it a linkable external dependency that is installed via this: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/tools/pip-requires"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-12 00:47:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Devin, John

Currently there is a openstack-common.conf file in the base directory of horizon. It is used  for the update.py script in openstack-common to indicate the common modules a project is using and update only the related files to the project. I guess the reason other OpenStack projects aren't putting openstack-common in to pip-requires is because we are in a transitional period towards openstack-common and the required functionalities has not yet settled."}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:07:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok, changing to a +2 based on that...'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:27:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

That makes sense.  Thanks for the explanation.  I'll approve this."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/818/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python26/84/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python27/84/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5030/ : SUCCESS
'}]

commit_message:
Horizon should use openstack.common.jsonutils

Implements blueprint use-common-jsonutils

1. Edit openstack-common.conf and import horizon/openstack/common/jsonutils.py
2. Remove json package imports and replace with jsonutils

Change-Id: I3b8e53f484eef8273fcb578474932f9d4e789881

Gabriel, all seem to work. I have just one question about the roles. As I can see one user can have multiple roles per project - at least the 'demo' user in devstack's setup is in roles 'anotherrole, Member'. However in the 'Add to project' form you can select only 1 role for a member. Is this intentional?"}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:13:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I did notice that. Funny what you learn when you expose data that wasn't visible before... ;-)

It's a feature worth having, for sure. It involves a bigger rewrite of the role management system, though, and I've been holding off on that until RBAC is really settled across all the projects and we can build a complete permission management system rather than just hacking around these roles."}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:15:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-12 02:33:58.000000000', 'message': 'Clarifying user roles in various places.

  * Adds a dropdown selector for the role you wish to grant a
    user on the default project during user creation.
    Fixes bug 999380.
  * Adds a "roles" column to the "Modify Users" table so you
    can see which roles users have been granted on a project.
    Fixes bug 1011919.
  * General table cleanup for readability.

Change-Id: Ic3f36903c78b52c70f66680f3956845e28656fd8
'}]
commit_message:
Clarifying user roles in various places.

  * Adds a dropdown selector for the role you wish to grant a
    user on the default project during user creation.
    Fixes bug 999380.
  * Adds a "roles" column to the "Modify Users" table so you
    can see which roles users have been granted on a project.
    Fixes bug 1011919.
  * General table cleanup for readability.

Change-Id: Ic3f36903c78b52c70f66680f3956845e28656fd8

commit_message:
Add build_sphinx options.

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc/source and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: Ibe6745cac73817ea06faca77367b4269d5137a24

  * Standardizes volume attachment wording.
  * Defensive coding for missing values in attachment dict.
    Fixes bug 1004412 and bug 1004337.
  * Adds polling to Snapshots and Volume Snapshots tables.
    Fixes bug 1005805.
  * Removes an erroneous link on the Volume Snapshots table.
    Fixes bug 1005806.
  * Correts the "type" property on the Images and Snapshots tables.
    Fixes bug 1011910.

This seems to restore all supported functionality related to volumes using
devstack master.

Change-Id: Ie9b7aec06fa1bb7628cd854fb49c02aab14451ea
'}]
commit_message:
Rollup of volume fixes.

  * Standardizes volume attachment wording.
  * Defensive coding for missing values in attachment dict.
    Fixes bug 1004412 and bug 1004337.
  * Adds polling to Snapshots and Volume Snapshots tables.
    Fixes bug 1005805.
  * Removes an erroneous link on the Volume Snapshots table.
    Fixes bug 1005806.
  * Correts the "type" property on the Images and Snapshots tables.
    Fixes bug 1011910.

This seems to restore all supported functionality related to volumes using
devstack master.

Change-Id: Ie9b7aec06fa1bb7628cd854fb49c02aab14451ea
