commit_message:
Fix libvirt rescue to work with whole disk images

 * fixes bug 1007266
 * passes rescue image data to get_config so it only adds
   the kernel and ramdisk if necessary
 * adds tests to make sure that the kernel and ramdisk
   only appear if they are needed

Change-Id: I32e0369a066ce2b6189b4a015b30ffd8b6d3ec66

commit_message:
Make live_migration a first-class compute API.

* Move the trivial implementation from admin_actions to compute.api
* Remove the dependency to scheduler from admin_actions
* Add check_instance_state like all other compute APIs to prevent
undesirable behavior

Change-Id: Ib5176718eae624de982f641bf3ec201fc7b4efcc

[{'created': '2012-06-06 22:16:01.000000000', 'message': "Add common dir for shared agent code, add OVS lib.

bp quantum-agent-common

Adds a common directory that can be used for code shared by agents for
different plugins.  Also seeds this directory with an OVS library,
removing that code from the openvswitch plugin itself.  This code
can then be leveraged by other plugins (e.g., Ryu) who have similar code.

Also add a suite of mox-based tests for OVS lib.

Also add more powerful OVS flow expression builder as suggested by
salv-orlando, plus additional flow expression testing.

Note: the expectation is that this directory will be used for much of the
agent functionality that is similar to what Nova's nova/network/linux_net.py
file included, such as iptables manipulation, dhcp manipulation, etc.

People should be careful about changing code in this directory in a
non-backward compatible way, as other plugins may be using the code as well.

Change-Id: I8fd15ec6b8016e85a3f02e0d756a3fd61b1cab15

commit_message:
Add common dir for shared agent code, add OVS lib.

bp quantum-agent-common

Adds a common directory that can be used for code shared by agents for
different plugins.  Also seeds this directory with an OVS library,
removing that code from the openvswitch plugin itself.  This code
can then be leveraged by other plugins (e.g., Ryu) who have similar code.

Also add a suite of mox-based tests for OVS lib.

Also add more powerful OVS flow expression builder as suggested by
salv-orlando, plus additional flow expression testing.

Note: the expectation is that this directory will be used for much of the
agent functionality that is similar to what Nova's nova/network/linux_net.py
file included, such as iptables manipulation, dhcp manipulation, etc.

People should be careful about changing code in this directory in a
non-backward compatible way, as other plugins may be using the code as well.

Change-Id: I8fd15ec6b8016e85a3f02e0d756a3fd61b1cab15

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-30 21:28:56.000000000', 'message': 'Update libvirt imagecache to support resizes.

Updates the libvirt image cache manage so that it accounts
for instances which are resizing.

Also fixes an issue where an exception was thrown when
the image cache manager ran while instances were resizing.
This is because instances which are resizing may have files in the
Nova instances directory which are missing backing files.

Fixes LP Bug #1006616.

Change-Id: I724c6855b68eca24a00893fd96b26b1443f9da5c
'}, {'created': '2012-05-31 11:04:59.000000000', 'message': 'Update libvirt imagecache to support resizes.

for instances which are resizing.

Also fixes an issue where an exception was thrown when
the image cache manager ran while instances were resizing.
This is because instances which are resizing may have files in the
Nova instances directory which are missing backing files.

Fixes LP Bug #1006616.

commit_message:
Update libvirt imagecache to support resizes.

Updates the libvirt image cache manage so that it accounts
for instances which are resizing.

Also fixes an issue where an exception was thrown when
the image cache manager ran while instances were resizing.
This is because instances which are resizing may have files in the
Nova instances directory which are missing backing files.

Fixes LP Bug #1006616.

Change-Id: I724c6855b68eca24a00893fd96b26b1443f9da5c

Padraig,

I actually think its better to leave XenServer unimplemented in this commit. By my testing the previous reboot didn't work on XenServer anyway... and would have failed miserably because XenServer doesn't allow you to send a reboot command to a halted instance (this is how instances are by default on reboot).

With this implementation at least we are being honest in that XenServer isn't going to work.

Once this goes in I'll put some work/testing into making it work on the XenServer side as well."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-06-01 16:11:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Oh in xen is already broken in this regard, then this is an improvement all round.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-01 18:27:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

dan i did some refactoring of the way domain creation is done in libvirt in the branch here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8020/3/nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py

I think you can use my new method:
create_domain_and_network to recreate the domain.  You can probably pull the domain from the existing definition like we do for rescue so you don't have to regenerate it:

dom = self._conn.lookupByName(instance['name'])
self.create_domain_and_network(dom.XMLDesc(0), instance, network_info)

alternatively do a little refactoring so that you can create the network for an existing domain properly.  My assumption in my refactor was that an existing domain would already have the network setup, but this isn't necessarily true on reboot."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-04 18:03:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Vish: Sure. I'll have a look at making this match your refactored domain creation. This is certainly the way to go for Folsom.

Initially I did this with a mind towards fixing this ticket in Essex. If we were to send this branch as is we could backport it to Essex today... and then refactor it to match the new way once your branches land.

Either way I'm fine."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-04 19:05:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-01 14:41:29.000000000', 'message': 'Implements resume_state_on_host_boot for libvirt.

Adds a new virt driver function to help resume guest states
on host boot. This fixes a couple issue with using a reboot
(like we did previously):

 * Using reboot would clear some task states (VERIFY_RESIZE for example)
 * Provides a mechanism for hypervisor specific guest restarts.
   Reboot would not have worked for XenServer for example...
 * Updates libvirt to use a hard reboot (instead of soft)

Fixes LP Bug #985162.

Change-Id: Iaf5aad75ec9b91f44710a18ddaf3a93378573a62
'}]
commit_message:
Implements resume_state_on_host_boot for libvirt.

Adds a new virt driver function to help resume guest states
on host boot. This fixes a couple issue with using a reboot
(like we did previously):

 * Using reboot would clear some task states (VERIFY_RESIZE for example)
 * Provides a mechanism for hypervisor specific guest restarts.
   Reboot would not have worked for XenServer for example...
 * Updates libvirt to use a hard reboot (instead of soft)

Fixes LP Bug #985162.

Change-Id: Iaf5aad75ec9b91f44710a18ddaf3a93378573a62

commit_message:
Bug #1007153

XS should not have the centos repo enabled by quantum this can break the system, also is possible to get the sqlalchemy from epel and avoid unneeded packages on the system.

Using epel rpm and leave it disabled after use

Change-Id: If6673e59afc545e51df3625d8259ec3fca9aaefb

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-02 06:39:45.000000000', 'message': "Auto generate AUTHORS file for python-glanceclient component.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

* AUTHORS
  Remove this file.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* glanceclient/openstack/common/setup.py
  Sync changes from openstack-common.

* setup.py
  Generate AUTHORS file before creating the package.

Change-Id: I9e9d4da5ca3b147b483250dcf25a3b2a840123c2

commit_message:
Auto generate AUTHORS file for glanceclient component.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

* AUTHORS
  Remove this file.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* glanceclient/openstack/common/setup.py
  Sync changes from openstack-common.

* setup.py
  Generate AUTHORS file before creating the package.

* glanceclient/shell.py
  Pep8 fix.

* tests/test_authors.py
  Remove this test case.

Change-Id: I9e9d4da5ca3b147b483250dcf25a3b2a840123c2

commit_message:
Add shared_storage_test methods to compute rpcapi.

Part of bug 1006467.

This patch adds 3 methods used to check if shared storage works between
two compute hosts to the compute rpcapi.  These methods are used by the
scheduler.

This also cuts down on some duplicated code in test_scheduler.

Change-Id: If0bf7f7fdd2beb0e5280ae52daf049372f8bc9e2

used by the scheduler.

Add remove_volume_connection to the compute rpcapi.

used by the compute manager.

messages:

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-python27/71/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Code looks great, but I wonder whether test_ovs_config should be placed in quantum/tests/unit or quantum/plugins/openvswitch/tests/unit

This test case is plugin specific unless it is meant to be used by all ovs-based plugins.

I will +2 once this is clarified.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Sounds reasonable to me.
Let's push it, then."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The openvswitch plugin was converted in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7869/'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is Bueno!'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

great, and thanks for the tests!'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

this looks good, but it fixes a bug introduced in a non-merged review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8101/

I'm curious why gerrit is not showing this as stacked?"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

ah, you're right.  the title of that merge only mentioned linuxbridge, so I missed the OVS changes."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's a good question Salvatore.  

This test can run without requiring any OVS dependencies to be installed, so I don't think there's much harm in having it in the main directory (other than perhaps less organization).  

Right now, only tests in this main test directory are run automatically when Jenkins merges, so I'd actually like more plugin specific tests to migrate to this directory over time, assuming they are properly mocked such that they can run without requiring any plugin-specific deps.  

So long story short, I'm fine keeping it in the main directory.  If things get cluttered with many plugin specific tests in the main directory (a good problem to have), we can create sub-directories.  Sound reasonable?"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks! Looks good.
Gary'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/74/ : SUCCESS
'}]

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 693, 'name': 'Christopher MacGown', 'email': 'chris@pistoncloud.com', 'username': '0x44'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1801, 'name': 'Duncan McGreggor', 'email': 'duncan.mcgreggor@rackspace.com', 'username': 'oubiwann'}, {'_account_id': 2031, 'name': 'Nachi Ueno', 'email': 'nati.ueno@gmail.com', 'username': 'nati-ueno'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 17:46:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 17:47:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Patch2 addresses pep8 issues.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:10:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hrm. I like the functionality, but I have one concern:

I don't like the fact that there are module-level objects whose state changes in other parts of the code. I think I'd be happier with a registry or component lookup system than mangling objects at the module level...

I know this is done in other areas of OpenStack, but it's a pretty bad code smell and anti-pattern. There are more maintainable, testable, explicit, and self-documenting ways of doing this.

That aside, the rest of it looks good to me."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:27:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Duncan, imho, the worst offenders in design are the reactors - I know they need some cleanup and redesign, but they also *work*. I'd like if that won't hold this back, especially due to the effort required to keep this maintained outside Nova with all the RPC changes that have been (and will be) coming through."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 18:42:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Resolving the smokestack complaints. Not all pep8 are created equal.

Also added the i18n to logs where it was missing, since no clear decision seems to be on that yet.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-21 19:28:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The unit tests appear to be busted."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 19:33:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The ZeroMQ unit tests require that bin/nova-rpc-zmq-receiver is running. I can roll this binary's functionality into the unit tests so that they'll work out of the box.

I just fixed the Kombu/Qpid unit tests which were failing because I broke the common unit test."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 19:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 19:39:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This rolls the functionality of the binary into the testing so that it will work out of the box. Perhaps later, I can abstract this so that the tests share more code with the binary.

Also fixed the rpc common tests for Kombu and Qpid.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:13:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

Awesome work, I like concept of ZMQ.
Some inline comments.
How can we change matchmaker driver?"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:34:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

(3 inline comments)

Replies to Nachi's comments in-line.

The matchmaker has its own blueprint, I'd hope that we can push this initial version of the matchmaker and later, through the matchmaker blueprint, potentially focus on a better architected version.  There seems to be some desire of exposing bindings/exchanges/queues for projects such as Ceilometer."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:55:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I've made some error checking improvements based on Nachi's comments. It should be noted that ZeroMQ is not going to generally error on connecting sockets outbound and that if a connection cannot be made, it will hit the RPC Timeout. Still, just in case, if any of this happens, I've made sure it raises an RPC Exception known by the abstraction layer per __init__.py.  (Note that these are zeromq "sockets" and not standard sockets)

I've also made sure that an error is noted if the IPC socket directory cannot be created.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:57:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:57:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Fixed some whitespace errors inserted while making Nachi's suggested changes."}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:11:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

"Duncan, imho, the worst offenders in design are the reactors - I know they need some cleanup and redesign, but they also *work*."

So, I'm not really sure how Twisted reactors ended up in this conversation (it is that to which you are referring, yes?). But let me clarify:

 * the use of global variables, in and of themselves, is not evil

 * global variables that can be modified in any number of places and which don't have any documentation are a maintenance nightmare and a liability to any project using them

 * if one *desperately* needs them and there's no way around it, one should create documentation or a documented API for interacting with them and then adhere to these as the only allowed means of changing said global data

"I'd like if that won't hold this back, especially due to the effort required to keep this maintained outside Nova with all the RPC changes that have been (and will be) coming through."

I don't believe that this is a valid criteria for merging any code. Any time it becomes hard maintaining a branch, we should offer leniency? I'm pretty sure the general consensus on code merges is that when they meet various quality standards and a core reviewer vouches for this, they are merged.

Regardless, you could fix this (poorly) by adding comments:
 * where the global variables are defined (noting what functions/methods are expected to update them and under what conditions), and
 * where they are used 

You could fix this in a better way by defining and using a simple API (e.g., some functions that are responsible for defining and updating them, and then only having your code use said functions).

You could fix it in the best way by identifying an approach that has more general acceptance as a best practice in the Python language community, ideally through discussion in the OpenStack and/or Python mail lists. I would imagine in a single day you could have the few conversations necessary to plan a solution.

With that latter approach, you would not only have improved your own code significantly, you would have also paved the way for fixing this problem in the rest of OpenStack.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:42:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

Thanks Eric

I got your point of machmaker and test code.
Thank you for your fixation of Error handling.

IMO, we should have ensure method something like kombu driver implements.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py#L487'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 22:50:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Duncan: The only globals are FLAGS, matchmaker, and ZMQ_CTX. They're all defined in register_opts, which is a mandatory initialization method. They're cleaned up in cleanup().

FLAGS is used globally throughout Nova and I'm not doing anything unusual here. The other rpc implementations have moved away from using this as a global, but I don't see the advantage of doing so besides code complexity, especially as the rest of Nova uses it as a global.

The matchmaker is simply memoized so that it isn't recreated. It isn't altered anywhere and it doesn't change after initialization, as is.
 
ZMQ_CTX does maintain state. It is also thread-safe. Unfortunately, with the RPC abstraction layer designed as it is and call/cast/notify/multi_call functions being outside a class, there isn't much alternative to making this a global.

Could these problems be changed through changes in the RPC abstraction? Sure. However, I'm not sure that should be done in this patch... I've tried to keep this patch from immediately touching the RPC abstraction and other parts of Nova."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 23:00:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

Notes to nachi'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 23:15:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 23:19:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Nachi, ZeroMQ handles reconnections and many (but not all) of the error conditions internally. My equivalent to the ensure method are at line 545 and 582. I use a Context to ensure that the socket is closed, to provide timeouts, and raise the errors that we want. ZeroMQ internally handles the reconnections.  Because a 'with' statement is already quite DRY, I didn't bother making a separate statement/block for this."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-05-21 23:35:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

That's sounds nice
Which file?"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 23:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(impl_zmq.py)'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-05-21 23:45:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-21 23:54:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Patch 7 includes comments to explain where the globals are defined.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-05-22 00:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks, Eric!'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-23 01:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-23 01:36:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I wrote a new test for rpc/common that checks casts and fixed a bug in calling the dispatcher and cleaned up that code.

I also added some comments as recommended by Joe Gordon. Made some other misc bugfixes and did some cleanup.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-23 02:09:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-23 02:10:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I see at least one syntax error (owing to limitations of Python 2.6 compliance) and several issues with spaces around docstrings that will likely result in errors from tools/hacking.py when the test suite is run.  Please be aware that I have not marked every instance of the docstring spacing issues, so make sure you find and fix them all.  It will be helpful to run the test suite, and I'd advise you to try to run it under both Python 2.6 and Python 2.7 to make sure there are no other version skew issues‚Ä¶"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-05-24 00:42:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Adds simple policy engine support

 * First step of blueprint interim-nova-authz-service
 * Common policy engine that can be used by other projects
 * Nova specific policy engine that uses common policy
 * Policy file can be generated by external tool (dashboard)
 * Ultimately, policies will be requested from a service

Change-Id: Icaf934037e790bde6ce2346746ce38b11134423b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-06 18:21:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up protocol case handling for security groups.

Fix bug 985184.

When creating security group rules, any case for the protocol was
accepted as input, such as TCP, Tcp, tcp, etc., and was stored in the
database as specified.  However, unless specified as all lowercase, the
code to apply the rules would break and result in some rules not being
applied.

(cherry picked from commit ff06c7c885dc94ed7c828e8cdbb8b5d850a7e654)

Change-Id: If737104f492aacd3688f04d78eb9bc993ffa33fc
'}]
commit_message:
Fix up protocol case handling for security groups.

Fix bug 985184.

When creating security group rules, any case for the protocol was
accepted as input, such as TCP, Tcp, tcp, etc., and was stored in the
database as specified.  However, unless specified as all lowercase, the
code to apply the rules would break and result in some rules not being
applied.

(cherry picked from commit ff06c7c885dc94ed7c828e8cdbb8b5d850a7e654)

Change-Id: If737104f492aacd3688f04d78eb9bc993ffa33fc

[{'created': '2012-06-05 15:16:17.000000000', 'message': "Added a check for attachment['instance']

The problem, described in the ticket occurs
while you try to attach a volume to instance,
while at the same time terminating the instance(
I've succeeded to reproduce it that way).
As seen from the stack trace - the error comes
after an AJAX call for updating the table rows.
In normal situations with loading the page,
this error should not appear. Anyway, now there
is a check to prevent this error.

Fixes bug 999502

Change-Id: Ifccc2cf724fe14098c74b55e65f8fbdd8c5434dc
"}]
commit_message:
Added a check for attachment['instance']

The problem, described in the ticket occurs
while you try to attach a volume to instance,
while at the same time terminating the instance(
I've succeeded to reproduce it that way).
As seen from the stack trace - the error comes
after an AJAX call for updating the table rows.
In normal situations with loading the page,
this error should not appear. Anyway, now there
is a check to prevent this error.

Fixes bug 999502

Change-Id: Ifccc2cf724fe14098c74b55e65f8fbdd8c5434dc

commit_message:
Revert "Add a load function wrapper to jsonutils"

This reverts commit 72840edc736b7f4d2366b5049f6516d8f5b901ff.

This change breaks kombu, so revert it since there is no specific need
for it.

Fixes bug 1009127.

Change-Id: Id0ef8b3948b63d0151289cb7ce8e617d9816bb4b

commit_message:
Changed project uuid to project name

in overview page, to keep consistency in
display views. At the moment UUID is only shown
for Detail views, and for Project/Users tables
in Syspanel, as there are no detail views for them.
Also a table caption was changed from Tenant to Project Name

Fixes bug 999392

Change-Id: Ie998d66d78fca713c33f61d2f62484e511097bf3

commit_message:
Fix up protocol case handling for security groups.

Fix bug 985184.

When creating security group rules, any case for the protocol was
accepted as input, such as TCP, Tcp, tcp, etc., and was stored in the
database as specified.  However, unless specified as all lowercase, the
code to apply the rules would break and result in some rules not being
applied.

Change-Id: I6c723d371579eb37a94bd484d39beeb773668ed4

commit_message:
Fixed bug with container reclaim/report race

Before, a really lagged cluster might not get its final report for a
deleted container database sent to its corresponding account
database. In such a case, the container database file would be
permanently deleted while still leaving the container listed in the
account database, never to be updated since the actual container
database file was gone. The only way to fix such the situation before
was to recreate and redelete the container.

Now, the container database file will not be permanently deleted
until it has sent its final report successfully to its corresponding
account database.

Change-Id: I1f42202455e7ecb0533b84ce7f45fcc7b98aeaa3

commit_message:
Use X_USER_NAME and X_ROLES headers.

- Don't use deprecated headers X_USER and X_ROLE but the newest one
  X_USER_NAME and X_ROLES.
- Fixes bug 999447.

Change-Id: I12752c7668863cbb47ee4b6e484cc494133443e8

Initial test failures are due to failed Jenkins slaves, caused by the original change that this reverts.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-05 01:32:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-05 02:28:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-05 02:35:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think I found the cause of the leak:

The tests that were added.. spin up a service with 2 workers, quickly sends a request and shuts down.

The service startup process loops creating workers until it hits 2.  Since the test runs so quickly..it tries to shut down in between creation worker 1 and worker 2 but:

170         while len(self.children) < self.workers:

that doesn't check to make sure 'self.running' is still True.

I'll comment on this in the patch.  There's other issues with it, too."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-06-05 04:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Approved

Patchset 3, addressed all comments in previous set.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-03-30 16:46:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-30 18:20:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi again, Zhiteng! Making great progress!

This code does, however, diverge a bit from the similar code in Swift and Glance, so I'm going to ask Chris Behrens to look over it to see if there are any other things he might be able to catch.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-03-31 01:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-03-31 01:53:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (4 inline comments)

Hi Jay,

Thank you. New patch set has been uploaded. If you or Chris have any suggestion, please let me know.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-06 15:27:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Hi again!

Almost there IMHO! Couple comments to remove (debug stuff) but other than that, looks great.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-09 22:09:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Huang! Another piece of advice I got from Ahmad (who did similar work on HP's Nova branch) was to ensure that the generate_uid() function inside nova/utils.py needs to be updated to pass a custom seed value that is process-specific, otherwise collisions occur...

HP used something like "Random String" + Process PID + <MACHINE IP> as the seed value...

Best,
-jay'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-17 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

To open this review again with newly updated changes.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-05-02 02:54:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-07 19:52:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

I would like to have you defend your choice to exclude "os" from the monkeypatching.  Also, see the notes inline on test_multiprocess_api.py.

I worked with a guy at HP who was trying to set up Turnstile in their version of a multiprocessing-adapted nova, and we turned up several issues with Turnstile in that environment.  I'll of course be looking into solving those issues so that Turnstile will be compatible with this patch, but I wanted to confirm that you have accounted for some of the subtleties that we turned up.  The primary one that we noted was shared data: each process has a full copy of the data elements that existed at the time the fork() occurred, but of course one process could not affect the data elements in another.  In Turnstile, this meant that reloading limits failed to operate properly.  I don't think that this directly affects nova, but have you considered that issue in testing this patch?

A secondary subtlety that we turned up is actually related to the primary one I note above: File descriptors are *also* shared across processes.  The implication for Turnstile was that one process issued a query to the database, but the answer to that query was received by a totally different process.  Again, I don't think nova is directly affected by this, but I wanted to ensure you considered that issue in testing this patch.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-05-08 08:53:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-08 14:36:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-05-08 16:16:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (5 inline comments)

Kevin, the reason I exclude 'os' in eventlet monkeypatching is monkeypatched os.wait() would return immediately, which is not expected behavior in wait_on_children() logic.

For the multiprocess concerns you mentioned, could you please be more specific?  For example, what exactly is the 'reloading limits' issue?  For shared file descriptor, I'll try to verify correctness of multiprocess DB query in unit test."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-08 16:52:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Kevin, the reason I exclude 'os' in eventlet monkeypatching
> is monkeypatched os.wait() would return immediately, which
> is not expected behavior in wait_on_children() logic.

OK, makes sense‚Ä¶

> For the multiprocess concerns you mentioned, could you
> please be more specific?  For example, what exactly is the
> 'reloading limits' issue?  

I'll have to go a little into the architecture of Turnstile to explain what I mean by that; sorry I wasn't completely clear in the previous comment.  Turnstile is a piece of middleware, like the existing rate limiting middleware.  When it is initialized, it starts a control daemon eventlet thread, which listens on a Redis connection queue for certain types of messages; when it receives those messages, it pulls limit configuration out of the database and stuffs it into an instance variable on the middleware.  The issue that we had getting Turnstile to work with HP's multiprocess environment is that the middleware and the control daemon were acting in two separate processes, so the control daemon could not actually update the limit configuration that the middleware was using.  This is obvious in hindsight, of course, and once we figured this out, we came up with a work-around fairly easily; all I'm asking is to make sure we don't have any similar problems anywhere in nova.  (I expect we don't; I'm just asking you to verify that.)

> For shared file descriptor, I'll
> try to verify correctness of multiprocess DB query in unit
> test.

Excellent :)"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-08 17:52:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/16270/ is example of the random.seed() usage from HP's branch that was needed to prevent collisions in nova.utils.generate_uid()"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-05-09 07:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-17 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-24 18:07:53.000000000', 'message': "blueprint multi-process-api-service

Add multiprocess support for API serivces (EC2/OSAPI_Compute/OSAPI_Volume/Metadata).
For description of this blueprint, please visit:
    https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/multi-process-api-service

2012-03-25 v1:
    * Modification to nova/service.py and nova/wsgi.py in order to support
    multiprocess (a.k.a. workers) for various API services.  If multiprocess
    mode is enabled, (i.e. flags 'APINAME_workers' set to positive numbers),
    corresponding API service will run in target number of process(es). There
    is also a master_worker process spawned for managing all workers (handling
    signal/termination).
    * Add unittest for multiprocess API service, also alter testing/runner.py
    to adopt new unittest.

    TODO: add metadata unittest.

Change-Id: Ia045e595543ddfd192894b2a05801cc4b7ca90cb

2012-03-27 v2:
    * Fixed unittest error.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Use self._logger to do logging in multiprocess mode.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Move self._pool creation into proper place.
    * code style fix.
2012-03-25 v1:
    * Modification to nova/service.py and nova/wsgi.py in order to support
    multiprocess (a.k.a. workers) for various API services.  If multiprocess
    mode is enabled, (i.e. flags 'APINAME_workers' set to positive numbers),
    corresponding API service will run in target number of process(es). There
    is also a master_worker process spawned for managing all workers (handling
    signal/termination).
    * Add unittest for multiprocess API service, also alter testing/runner.py
    to adopt new unittest.

Change-Id: Ia045e595543ddfd192894b2a05801cc4b7ca90cb

commit_message:
blueprint <multi-process-api-service>

Add multiprocess support for API serivces (EC2/OSAPI_Compute/OSAPI_Volume/Metadata).

2012-06-1 v7:
    * Add unittest to cover worker recovery, service termination functionality
    in wsgi.py, fix python 2.6 compatibility issue.
    * Modify generate_uid() to introduce per-process seeds in utils.py to avoid
    collisions.
    * Add worker session to nova.conf.sample.
2012-05-21 v6:
    * Fix 'test_wsgi' unittest error.
2012-04-28 v5:
    * Add SIGINT handler and fix child-parent race condition when Ctrl+C is
    pressed.
2012-03-31 v4:
    * Fixed typo, removed debug code.
2012-03-30 v3:
    * Fixed localization/pep8 error in unittest, add metadata test.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: use the greenthread pool created for each process.
    * nova/service.py: remove debug code
2012-03-27 v2:
    * Fixed unittest error.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Use self._logger to do logging in multiprocess mode.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Move self._pool creation into proper place.
    * code style fix.
2012-03-25 v1:
    * Modification to nova/service.py and nova/wsgi.py in order to support
    multiprocess (a.k.a. workers) for various API services.  If multiprocess
    mode is enabled, (i.e. flags 'APINAME_workers' set to positive numbers),
    corresponding API service will run in target number of process(es). There
    is also a master_worker process spawned for managing all workers (handling
    signal/termination).
    * Add unittest for multiprocess API service, also alter testing/runner.py
    to adopt new unittest.

Change-Id: Ia045e595543ddfd192894b2a05801cc4b7ca90cb

subject: Add cfg's new global CONF object
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}]

Ugh, I really can't stand the global config object. I thought it was to be *optional*, not required, as this code makes it..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-29 19:32:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-pep8/23/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-merge/23/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python26/23/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python27/23/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-30 11:29:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Mark,

Overall I'm not a fan of the global CONF object approach, however in this case I'd have to reluctantly concede that the value in aligning with the other openstack project trumps my aversion.

One question/suggestion though ... there's a recurring pattern in the patch where options that were previously defined/registered at class-level scope close to where they're are used, are now registered at module-level scope. Is this move necessary? Could the CONF variable continue to be defined at module-level scope, but the option registration remain where it is currently?

This would seem to be a less disruptive change, and would retain the advantage of options being introduced in the code closer to where they are used.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-30 12:57:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Ugh, I really can't stand the global config object. I 
> thought it was to be *optional*, not required, as this 
> code makes it...

As I've said from the start:

  https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg08329.html

  I really think it will be beneficial if we can share 
  common idioms and patterns across projects, rather than 
  just using the same library in different ways

My instinct is to avoid using a global object, but I care much more about sharing the same patterns across OpenStack projects.

Also, the more I try - and you have to admit, I've tried pretty damn hard - to defend the "global objects, ugh!" position, the arguments appear fairly weak. Pragmatically speaking, it causes few practical problems whereas passing a conf object around everywhere is truly a pain in the arse.

Please actually checkout the tree from I222d3c58308bc2f504cd802c0c8405d3baa2e49a and poke around. I actually quite like the end result. In comparison, I don't think I'd like the end result of a patch to remove the global object from Nova - the pain of passing around a conf object there would be massive.

The "share common idioms, not just common code" thing isn't just a stylistic thing either. We're in the process of moving the RPC API into openstack-common and it will be quite painful to support global and non-global cfg usage. Another example would be if we wanted to move the auth_token middleware configuration out of paste.ini into the main config files, we'd need to support global and non-global config. And the same will be true for a bunch of other stuff we want to move into openstack-common.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-30 13:02:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Overall I'm not a fan of the global CONF object approach, 
> however in this case I'd have to reluctantly concede that 
> the value in aligning with the other openstack project 
> trumps my aversion.

Thanks! :)

> One question/suggestion though ... there's a recurring 
> pattern in the patch where options that were previously 
> defined/registered at class-level scope close to where 
> they're are used, are now registered at module-level 
> scope. Is this move necessary? Could the CONF variable 
> continue to be defined at module-level scope, but the 
> option registration remain where it is currently?

That's a fair question. I do have a slight preference for the option scoping we achieved in places in glance, but it didn't always work out so well - e.g. the likes of wsgi.get_bind_addr()

I see the module-level option definition thing as part of the common idiom here and it's what Nova and Keystone do.

Also, in Nova, there's work in progress on a tool to pull all the option schemas from the code and generate a sample config file. This tool relies on options being defined at module import time. It'd be nice for this tool to be able to evolve to a point that all projects can use it."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-30 13:02:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-30 13:30:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-pep8/32/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-merge/32/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python26/32/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python27/32/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-30 13:37:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

> there's work in progress on a tool to pull all the option
> schemas from the code and generate a sample config file.
> This tool relies on options being defined at module import
> time. It'd be nice for this tool to be able to evolve to a
> point that all projects can use it.

That's a good enough reason.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-30 15:12:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Accepting that the common idiom goal will require some projects to change their idiom, why did you choose to move in the direction of global CONF rather than the other way around?'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-30 15:33:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Accepting that the common idiom goal will require some projects to change their idiom, why did you choose to move in the direction of global CONF rather than the other way around?

Because - while it was difficult to get many people to express much of an opinion either way - I got a strong impression that a lot of folks valued the simplicity of the global approach.

https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg12418.html

Also, comparing the amount of code in OpenStack core using the global approach (i.e. Nova and Keystone) vs code using the non-global approach (i.e. Glance) I think the pragmatic approach is to accept that global is the most prevalent idiom. I don't think anyone relishes the prospect of a patch to move Nova to non-global.

I did my best to shift consensus towards the non-global approach and I failed. I can now clearly see very good pragmatic arguments for the global approach."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-30 17:49:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Mark,

I was quite impressed by your arguments about avoiding global objects--however, that means: if you are satisfied that we can easily deal with any problems global CONF might cause, then so am I.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-30 19:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Sure, whatever... it's better to be consistent than not. But, what really annoys me is that termie's insistence on keeping the "config shortcuts" in Keystone is being placated and yet my issues with the global conf object are ignored. :('}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-30 21:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-30 21:54:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-pep8/38/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-merge/38/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python26/38/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python27/38/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-31 09:22:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-31 18:06:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Why do we need to define a module-level CONF everywhere we import the cfg module? Why not just reference cfg.CONF directly?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 18:32:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Why do we need to define a module-level CONF everywhere we import the cfg module? Why not just reference cfg.CONF directly?

Fair question, it seems to just be the pattern

You can see it being copied in Nova with QUOTAS. You see it with BASE in glance.registry.db.api too'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-31 18:43:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I don't think there's much sense in the pattern if you aren't doing any work with it. It makes sense for LOG, where a logger is created, saving a getLogger call all over the code. It also makes sense for assigning a shorter alias to a long module path. In this case, we already have a short module path 'cfg.CONF'. I would prefer if that part of this patch were removed."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-31 20:00:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> I don't think there's much sense in the pattern if you aren't doing any work with it. It makes sense for LOG, where a logger is created, saving a getLogger call all over the code. It also makes sense for assigning a shorter alias to a long module path. In this case, we already have a short module path 'cfg.CONF'. I would prefer if that part of this patch were removed.

As discussed, the whole point of what we're doing here is trying to get to a common pattern across OpenStack. Why adopt the common pattern in glance and then have it be arbitrarily slightly different?

i.e. I'd be very happy for you to later put forward those arguments and propose s/CONF/cfg.CONF/ patches for the core projects, but I'd be very sad if glance had cfg.CONF and other projects had CONF for fairly minor reasons"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-01 18:23:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Why is adding an arbitrary line of code something we need to duplicate? These are independent projects being run by somewhat independent groups of people. We don't need to do things in this project just because we do in another. Why should Glance be required to conform to whatever nova-core approves?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-03 08:56:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Why be arbitrarily different?

What do you think it says about OpenStack if we have to tell contributors "type CONF in project A, B and C but type cfg.CONF in project D"?

I'm not trying to "require" Glance to "conform" to anything. I just think this kind of arbitrary deviation from the idiom used by other projects is downright silly.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-04 19:03:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I'm about done arguing over this...

I'm not asking for an arbitrary difference. I've clearly explained why it is objectively better to leave out the 'CONF = cfg.CONF' lines. This is not just a personal preference.

With that said, I'm going to approve this so you can move on with any other work."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-04 20:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4508/ : FAILURE

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/888/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/397/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/399/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-05 21:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-05 21:19:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thanks Brian.

Just to clarify - "arbitrary difference" was not about whether your comment made sense or not, it was about how arbitrary "these projects do it this way and that project it does it that way" would appear to new contributors'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-05 21:30:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Add cfg's new global CONF object

Implements blueprint cfg-global-object

Begin adopting cfg's global CONF object pattern rather than passing
a conf object around everywhere.

This iterations does just enough to have each of the glance programs
initialize CONF and get the unit tests working.

Change-Id: Ia34959b3ba52cbe933d5d347f31319271b2e14f9

subject: Implementation of tenant,user,role list functions for ldap
messages:
[{'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-23 14:57:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

These were intentionally not implemented, so I'd like to get reviews from those who implementing LDAP in production before merging."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-23 14:58:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

pep8"}, {'account_id': 3131, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:13:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-23 18:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

+2 pending feedback from LDAP stakeholders'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-04-25 16:47:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

this seems fine to me if ayoung agrees'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-04-30 15:22:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Want ayoung review before approving'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-05-03 19:47:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

ping ayoung'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-05-14 17:14:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

While the implementations look clear enough,  I have a couple questons.

1.  Termie has a comment in keystone/identity/core.py:Driver: " I'd prefer if this listed only the users for a given tenant".  Is the intention to comply with this or to show the global list?  THis version shows the Global list,  and I am not sure that is a pattern we want to continue.

2.  There is no get_tenants API in the driver.  The other functions are both list_  but this one is a get.  Should we be consistent?

3.  How is this to be used?  I don't think there are Public URLs that can access either of these calls yet,  so what is the purpose of implementing them?  

If there are any URIs that are implemented for SQL but not LDAP , please open tickets for them.

Sorry so slow in reviewing,  I just stubled across the request today.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-22 21:19:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Any updates on the above questions, or should this be pushed targeted at f2?'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-05-29 20:28:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Derek,

Would you mind answering ayoung's questions, and assuming he's OK with the setup, we'll approve and merge this through."}, {'account_id': 3131, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:28:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

1. Termie has a comment in keystone/identity/core.py:Driver: " I'd prefer if this listed only the users for a given tenant". Is the intention to comply with this or to show the global list? THis version shows the Global list, and I am not sure that is a pattern we want to continue.

I would comply with whatever the convention is.  Since the SQL driver allows to not specify a tenant and therefore listing all users it knows about that is what I implemented here.

2. There is no get_tenants API in the driver. The other functions are both list_ but this one is a get. Should we be consistent?

I implemented only what I was getting called as so the change was only within the LDAP driver.  That decision would need to be up the stack in the classes above which I don't think is the scope of this change.  My opinion would to be consistent but I was looking to just provide a consistency with the SQL outputs on the command line.

3. How is this to be used? I don't think there are Public URLs that can access either of these calls yet, so what is the purpose of implementing them?

It seems helpful to me to be able to interrogate the backend driver to ensure you are getting correct results without having to go to a public application.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-06 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-06 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Implementation of tenant,user,role list functions for ldap

Bug 983304

Defines functions for the retrival and return of the tenant, user and
role objects in ldap.  They will return in whatever order LDAP provides
them.

Additional fix for pep8 whitespace violation.

Change-Id: I0e0924b716be943dcb57ec95baf42070b115d169

'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2012-05-24 22:26:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 739, 'date': '2012-05-25 16:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Guys, i hit another issue with webob 1.2. Can yall make sure its covered here. I was using 1.2 from glance to send down a image to swift and hit this error via the webob 1.2 LimitedLengthFile. Thx!

  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/swift/common/client.py", line 935, in put_object
    orig_pos = tell()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/io.py", line 1021, in tell
    return self.raw.tell() - len(self._read_buf) + self._read_pos
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/io.py", line 354, in tell
    return self.seek(0, 1)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/io.py", line 350, in seek
    self._unsupported("seek")
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/io.py", line 333, in _unsupported
    (self.__class__.__name__, name))
UnsupportedOperation: LimitedLengthFile.seek() not supported'}, {'account_id': 4405, 'date': '2012-05-25 17:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

oops, I've been trying to fix bug 888371, and today I got unittests passed version to fix the bug, and waiting to my CLA process is finished.

But there's another approach here :(

I only check the bug 888371, and there's no action, so I thought nobody working on the webob issue.
Because I'm new to this project, I can't sure what should I do.
Shoud I just create new review of bug 888371 with my code or just help this review to fix same issue?

Anyway, this patchset 3 failed to pass .functests with both web 1.0.8 & web 1.2b3

Some of error messages are like this:

======================================================================
ERROR: testFileListingLimitMarkerPrefix (test.functional.tests.TestContainerUTF8)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/simple/swift/test/functional/tests.py", line 396, in testFileListingLimitMarkerPrefix
    self.assert_(cont.files(parms={'marker': f, 'prefix':f}) == [])
  File "/home/simple/swift/test/functional/swift.py", line 454, in files
    raise ResponseError(self.conn.response)
ResponseError: 503: Internal Server Error

======================================================================
ERROR: testPrefixAndLimit (test.functional.tests.TestContainerUTF8)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/simple/swift/test/functional/tests.py", line 419, in testPrefixAndLimit
    files = cont.files(parms={'prefix':prefix})
  File "/home/simple/swift/test/functional/swift.py", line 454, in files
    raise ResponseError(self.conn.response)
ResponseError: 503: Internal Server Error

----------------------------------------------------------------------

commit_message:
Adapt Swift for Webob 1.2b3

Existing Swift code targets Webob 1.0.8 and continues to work with
Webob 1.1.1, using the compatibility and throwing a few deprecation
warnings. However, Webob 1.2 moved on from deprecation to outright
removal of certain API features that we need. Also, it moved to
the "more Pythonic" way of dealing with strings, e.g. all-unicode
and border transformation.

This changeset produces a common Swift code that runs on both
Webob 1.0.x and Webob 1.2.x. It is desirable for packagers working
with long-term Linux distributions.

The following compatibility issues were addressed:

- str_params is gone. Use params instead.
  This requires updating tests, too.

- A UTF-8-encoded argument to parameter format= leaks into HTTP header
  Content-Type, and this tracebacks, because Webob does not allow UTF-8
  in HTTP headers. The fix is to allow only "xml", "json", and "plain"
  in format= query argument. This is a compatibility change: previously
  it was possible to set any garbage there, and receive garbage HTTP
  headers with 200 OK code.

- resp.environ is gone. Use req.environ instead.

- req.range.ranges is no more, only one range is supported.

- UTF-8 keys traceback all around. Operations such as quote()
  and join() in particular cannot work unless arguments match.

  Basically, any attempt to access self.path_info blows up.

  The only realistic fix that we found was forcing the Request
  encoding to 1:1 or "identity" encoding (known as 'latin-1').

- Same thing happens in all other servers: account, container
  and object. However, it is feasible there to use the Pythonic
  way and go all-unicode. The fix in this changeset is incomplete
  in that it changes the 412 return code to 500 when Request
  fails to parse before check_utf8 has a chance to trigger.
  This is never seen by the user since Proxy server filters
  requests for us. This may need fixing properly.

- Webob 1.2b3 seems to have a bug that makes the following to blow up:
    req.range = req.range

  This is because the property accessors produce Range object on
  get, but do not take Range on put.

This version of the patch adds fixes for tempurl middleware
since it was re-accepted into the tree.

Not all functional tests appear to pass with this. We are working
on sorting it out. All unit tests pass.

Bug: 959881
Change-Id: Ic4af9aba66452214087efe2d664a7a9aca86bd7a

commit_message:

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-31 23:03:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work; I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-pep8/176/ : UNSTABLE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-merge/176/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python27/179/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python26/178/ : FAILURE"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-01 01:26:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hmmm... Could someone explain why we need this now?

I just deleted a flavor... and then tried to create an instance with the same (deleted) flavor ID. The instance went into an ERROR state (as I would expect)....

It would seem that we already prevent *new* instances from being created with a deleted flavors.

Additionally we just added some branches which allow you to view deleted flavors. This would seem to cover the case for *live* instances.

----

Is the motivation behind this change simply that we want the instance boot to fail earlier. Why isn't what we currently have good enough?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-01 10:47:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python27/196/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-pep8/193/ : UNSTABLE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-merge/193/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python26/195/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 4419, 'date': '2012-06-01 14:33:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

One usage scenario is phasing out a well used flavor.

We don't want to just kill the existing instances, but we don't want to allow customers to build nor resize to those instances.

We **don't** want customers to be able to list the phasing out (disabled) instance_types in the flavor list.

We **do** want admins to see that it's there and to see the 'disabled' metadata.

When a customer does a 'show' or detail on their 'instance' we want it to show the instance type name; for this reason we've left the 'show' of the disabled flavors in there.

So in summary, we disable the instance type to stop people being able to build from it.

We couldn't do this with the deleted flag as 'openstack.compute.flavors.index' and 'detail' only show non-deleted flavors and that's probably the right way to do it.

The one concern I have is in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8007/1/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/flavors.py on line 56. We're returning the disabled flag in it's own namespace, as if it were coming from an extension.

The reasoning behind this is:
 * If we did it as an extension, it would greatly complicate the code. The code is much simpler being right in the core code.
 * We can't just add a field to the API quickly, so we need to use the namespace.
 * The hope is that eventually it would be accepted into the  main API anyway, then the coding would be just removing the namespace.

I'll be interested to see what other people think."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-01 16:07:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If the primary use case here is to support REBUILD with a 'deleted' flavors I actually think we could pull this off without too much trouble. We'd just need to update a couple more functions in instance_types.py so that they can read 'deleted' flavors and then put in some extra checks to disallow new instances from being spawned with a deleted flavor.

This would allow REBUILD's to continue to occur with the deleted flavor and might work better with the core OpenStack flavors SPEC.

Rick, maybe we can catch up on IRC. I'm not entirely sold that using an API extension is required for this."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-01 17:31:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:29:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

See inline... kind of feel like we should follow existing paradigms. When doing queries for flavors from existing instances or service operations, just supply the deleted=None param to always bring back flavor information, regardless of deleted status."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-06-04 21:00:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-06-05 16:09:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm fine with this, as long as it's eventually followed up with a patch that's being discussed on the ML right now.

Looks like there may be some PEP8 errors."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-06-05 19:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-05 19:44:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Adds `disabled` field for instance-types.

The `disabled` field is intended to be used when phasing out
instance-types. In this case, a delete wouldn't work because the
instance-type needs to still be available for live instances using that
type, but we don't want to allow *new* instances created from that type.

In addition, we don't want to list hidden instance-types for regular
users, but we *do* want to list them for admin-users to ensure they have
a complete view of what's going on in the system.

Once all references to the phased-out instance-type have been dropped,
it would be safe to mark the instance-type as `deleted=True`.

Change-Id: I2af1c027f4d8114aee31353007dfdd3d0bb679ed

[EnvInject] - [ERROR] - SEVERE ERROR occurs: hudson.remoting.ChannelClosedException: channel is already closed
Notifying upstream projects of job completion
[EnvInject] - [ERROR] - SEVERE ERROR occurs: channel is already closed"}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-06-05 08:43:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Gabriel,

It seems this commit broke the Create Instance workflow. The problem occurs at starting a new instance in Syspanel(starting an instance in Nova is OK).

There is an error in Horizon log:
[Tue Jun 05 10:50:37 2012] [error]     "required but not present." % ", ".join(missing))
[Tue Jun 05 10:50:37 2012] [error] WorkflowValidationError: Unable to complete the workflow. The values project_id are required but not present.

And an error is displayed in UI:
Error: There was an error submitting the form. Please try again.

I see you've added a call to is_valid() in workflows.base, and it raises an error because project_id is not present. The difference comes from get_initial - 


class LaunchInstanceView(workflows.WorkflowView):

    def get_initial(self):
        initial = super(LaunchInstanceView, self).get_initial()
        initial['project_id'] = self.request.user.tenant_id


while initial['project_id'] is not set in 

class AdminLaunchView(LaunchInstanceView):

And now is_valid raises an error for that, because the line :
            self.context = step.contribute(request.POST, self.context)	

appear after calling is_valid, and it is that line that prefills project_id in the context in the previous version.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-06-05 19:41:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-06-05 19:42:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good catch, Tihomir :-)

I've updated the patch with both a fix and an additional unit test to verify the syspanel launch behavior works in the future."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-05 19:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/75/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This code was originally in nova.utils, which was certainly imported before kombu was used.

After being moved to jsonutils, it is still imported before kombu is used.  It is imported by nova.rpc.common.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I just discovered that python-kombu is using anyjson.  That would make explain where this came from.  That means that if something makes it all the way into kombu that can't be json serialized, it gets forced back through this code so to_primitive() can fix it up."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

At least in nova, I think this module is used directly.  I haven't actually seen use of anyjson anywhere, even though this anyjson handling came from nova... I guess that would mean the current strategy is:

1) Always use this code directly.

2) If someone were to happen to add 3rd party code that uses anyjson, we have it covered to use this code.

It seems a little odd.  The anyjson stuff could probably just go away, but I guess it doesn't cost much to have it ..."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Zhongyue, could you add a comment based on the information Russell found?

How do we know for sure that this module is loaded before kombu? Does the impl_kombu module from the rpc package do it?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm curious about the history of this wrapper module, too. It looks like we are using anyjson to select a json library, but if this module is imported it forces anyjson to always use the implementation provided here. Does something guarantee that this module is imported, so all json calls go through here? Or is it possible that some of the other packages use anyjson without importing this? If we always want to use these wrappers, should there be a blueprint/bug to replace the use of anyjson in the other projects?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah, it's not expensive except in terms of the periodic "why is this here?" questions. :-)'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-06 00:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Doug: Will do'}]

Add a load function wrapper to jsonutils

Excellent stuff. thanks!
I've a few suggestions inline.

Note probably the most accurate/up to date source for this material is at https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Getting_started_with_OpenStack_EPEL"}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-05-20 04:08:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Looks great - especially if p-draigbrady comments are accepted. Added one more potential place for an install command in-line.

I note that the prompt changes from '$' to '#' throughout the document, but that is so seriously 'cosmetic' in importance ;)"}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-05-20 16:56:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

This looks a good way to start.

Ultimately, I think it would be really cool if we could use XML to mark up distribution-specific content and generate a separate manual for each distribution.  For example, something like:

<distro>
 <ubuntu>apt-get install foo</ubuntu>
 <fedora>yum install foo</fedora>
</distro>

But I'd rather start getting this content in now.

I'd also like to see a section at the beginning that discusses how well supported OpenStack is on different distributions. In particular, there are some distributions where OpenStack is a "first-class citizen" (Ubuntu, Fedora) in the sense that the distribution has official packages. There are other distros where there is package support provided by third parties (e.g., SLES).

I have no idea what the state of OpenStack is on RHEL. Do we use official Fedora packages for that? GridDynamics packages? And are CentOS and Scientific Linux supported by being RHEL-alike, or are there people on those projects that look at OpenStack support?'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-05-20 16:58:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I see by the title of this patch that it's really about Fedora/RHEL/Centos at this point, so comments about other distros are out of scope here."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-05-20 16:59:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-20 20:30:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

A couple of comments inline, the main one being to remove the --enablerepo yum option from yum commands'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-05-25 19:44:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-28 00:15:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: (4 inline comments)

amazing work"}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-05-31 00:12:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

to:

    force_dhcp_release

Was that intended. Otherwise this is a fantastic update to the docs. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-05-31 15:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

So the --force_ dhcp_release=True being removed came from a merge with master, Razique's change at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7871/.

However Devstack still has

in their scripts. Maybe we need to revisit.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-06-01 00:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-06-01 01:33:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)
