commit_message:
Adding Fedora/RHEL/Centos instructions.

6/4/12: Ah ha, fixes openstack-keystone-essex to openstack-keystone.
Adds yum commands to all swift installation.
Further testing, add sed commands to substitute IP addresses.

Fixes pom file to hopefully publish two separate guides on Jenkins.

Thanks for all the reviews - going to publish this one since it's in demand.

Rebased against master to include great new chapters about registering and running VMs.

Nearly through Compute testing, dashboard next.
Continuing the walkthrough testing with a VM, editing as I go.

Changed the force_dhcp_release=True line in nova.conf.

Updated pom.xml to use 1.3.1 of the cloud doc tools Maven, also set centos as OS in the pom.xml.

Removed separate chapter files and putting markup throughout to indicate os as an attribute
on certain commands.

Adds "Troubleshooting the Image Service" though it doesn't have much more info than where the log files are located.

Updated pom.xml so that it will filter based on the value of
the profile.os maven property.
Updated the identity_install_keystone.xml source file to use the os attribute
attribute for filtering based on operating system (ubuntu, rhel, etc). Using
a <screen>s and <para>s as examples.

Addressing comments about RHEL and Fedora.

Feedback welcome.

Rebase against master.

Change-Id: Idd81d39567a89fb6905901dab9551ecfe27ee847

subject: Replace datetime.utcnow with timeutils.utcnow
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason K√∂lker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1994, 'name': 'Zhongyue Luo', 'email': 'zhongyue.luo@gmail.com', 'username': 'zyluo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

+1 on just removing all the override time stuff.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The override time stuff is used by nova unit tests.  Right now it's still using the same code in nova.utils instead, but it could (and should) be using this instead."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Doug,

Checkout https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7720/1/nova/utils.py'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree. I personally wanted utcnow.override_time out of the code.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The override time stuff is used in nova ..."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Oh maybe I misunderstood. I though override_time was to be removed from openstack-common while Nova still uses it in its utils module. And it is future work to remove override_time from Nova and switch the datetime functions in utils with timeutils. Am I on the right track?'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I kept the utcnow function to keep the entropy low. If there is no particular merit for utcnow then it should be removed in the future.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Nova is not using the override time stuff from openstack-common, but it could.  My point was that there is a use for it.  It isn't arbitrary and not used anywhere.  I think it should only be removed if determined that its use in nova is unnecessary and is removed.  Otherwise, I'd rather see nova get converted to use the version from openstack-common than to remove it from here."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

In that case, how about a patch that removes that functionality? It looks like the useful time-related functions are parse_isotime() (only because of the exception handling) and normalize_time(). There's no need for a utcnow() wrapper without the override variable and the isotime() function looks like a re-implementation of datetime.datetime.isoformat()."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I *really* don't like the idea of building test features into library code like this. If a test needs to ensure a specific time value is returned by the time code, it should use the mock or mox library tools for temporarily replacing that function."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Just use pure nosetests.

The test suite can be run now with pure nosetests + the openstack nose
plugin. There is no longer any need for the run_tests.py.

Change-Id: Iad89a2c1cc567ba10919a52166b3309edef20009

could benefit from some simple unit tests to cover the context code, but other than that, I think this is good.   I'm fine with it going in as is, assuming my assumption about the DB stuff is correct."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Did the CI folks change the pep8 version/options again?  Jenkins is unhappy: https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-pep8/58/console'}, {'account_id': 452, 'date': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 452, 'date': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Besides one concern, I think this changeset is great!"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

> In general these codes are from nova project. Right?

No.  The nova code was used as a model, but the exact code was tailored to the needs and uses of Quantum.  I should also mention that the context code was written by Dragon, intended for persisting the session in addition to its other functions, and I merely grabbed that and made a couple of slight additions needed for the requisite record keeping (i.e., coupling roles to admin permissions).

> I think we should wait the authz to decide what features
> we need in the context class. So that the context will be
> much cleaner.

The stuff in the current context class is the minimum required to get the job done, with the additional piece of persisting the database session (which, frankly, is also required and should be in nova but isn't at present).  Waiting for authz will not buy any increase in cleanliness for the context class.

> I think this context should submitted together with other
> parts of authz, so that the codes will glue together and
> make more sense.

In the sense of prohibiting unauthenticated users from accessing Quantum, this code is ready to go as-is.  In terms of authz, that depends significantly on the exact specification of the v2 API (since authz is not wanted as part of v1), and the exact structure of the v2 API seems to still be in significant flux.  I was lead to believe that the authn piece should be pushed upstream now, as it represents a completed work, which is why I went to the trouble of submitting it."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-05 20:50:08.000000000', 'message': "AuthN support for Quantum

Adds authentication support for Quantum.  Generates a context object
and stuffs it into the 'quantum.context' variable in the WSGI environment.

commit_message:
AuthN support for Quantum

Adds authentication support for Quantum.  Generates a context object
and stuffs it into the 'quantum.context' variable in the WSGI environment.
This will be used in conjunction with authZ, later.

Partially implements blueprint authorization-support-for-quantum.

Change-Id: I8af171c2f11a08db5ee41e609d60ad203548650d

commit_message:
fix the instance quota overlimit message

This addresses two closely related bugs.

Bug: 998199
Fix the "used" and "total" counts
in the returned diagnostic.

Bug: 902218
Itemize instance quota items exceeded,
in the returned diagnostic.

Change-Id: Iff7781a7fb53545d44c2b4ec0ca6d65114723c8d

Create a new base network test case that raises skip
if no network endpoint is found in Keystone.

commit_message:
cleanup power state (partially implements bp task-management)

Removed duplicate and invalid state in power_state:
FAILED, SHUTOFF, BLOCKED
This is the first step in cleaning up nova state machine
and do better task management (bp/task-management)

http://wiki.openstack.org/VMState

Change-Id: I586b9058fada5efd468870fb187590fc0e37aa8f

commit_message:
Sync with latest version of openstack.common.cfg

Changes since last sync:

 - make reset() clear defaults and overrides
 - automatically create option groups
 - allow options to be marked as required
 - use a list comprehension instead of map()

Change-Id: Id259a7ffe791a7e272fcc8bb21d7d0bc4f9e591d

commit_message:
Updated image example to cirros, add boot section

Updated the section on uploading images to use the newer CirrOS images rather
than the old ttylinux image.

Added a section on booting an instance from the command-line.

Removed images-uploading.xml since it seems to be unused.

Cherry picked from https://review.openstack.org/7830

Change-Id: Ib05b0b8c12c56c21feb2b7e043cf65f52a62a67c

[{'created': '2012-06-01 00:04:34.000000000', 'message': 'Finish removing xenapi.HelperBase class

The XenAPI driver has the concept of helper classes. All methods
have been classmethods and the classes themselves are never
instantiated. As a result, they only add an extra namespace
lookup and provide no value.

This is the last patch in this series

Change-Id: I314dfa6555d38be9b0988270b3367c4ae86b19bb
'}]
commit_message:
Finish removing xenapi.HelperBase class

The XenAPI driver has the concept of helper classes. All methods
have been classmethods and the classes themselves are never
instantiated. As a result, they only add an extra namespace
lookup and provide no value.

This is the last patch in this series

Change-Id: I314dfa6555d38be9b0988270b3367c4ae86b19bb

commit_message:
Remove network_util.NetworkHelper class

The XenAPI driver has the concept of helper classes. All methods
have been classmethods and the classes themselves are never
instantiated. As a result, they only add an extra namespace
lookup and provide no value.

Change-Id: Ief7d51013d8f313ca8c78cb157599858b156ac3f

The XenAPI driver has the concept of helper classes. All methods

commit_message:
Start removing unnecessary classes from XenAPI driver

The XenAPI driver has the concept of helper classes. All methods
have been classmethods and the classes themselves are never
instantiated. As a result, they only add an extra namespace
lookup and provide no value.

The first step is to move some functions from HelperBase to the
session class where it is better suited.

Change-Id: I13d6d49509052d35339a0ef132647bd61179cdd8

commit_message:
Remove volume_util.VolumeHelper class

The XenAPI driver has the concept of helper classes. All methods
have been classmethods and the classes themselves are never
instantiated. As a result, they only add an extra namespace
lookup and provide no value.

Change-Id: I26d1adfd378adc0728388185ba81fc4c71a41bdc

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-31 13:00:46.000000000', 'message': "XenAPI: Don't hardcode userdevice for VBDs

Cleanup and refactor the way VBDs are allocated so it's clearer what
userdevice each VDI is allocated to. Also, use a dict of VDIs instead
of a list since it's nonsensical to have multiple VDIs of any type
and simplifies the code somewhat.

Change-Id: I46d6215dbd90822970a874af66f22c9a34529a40
"}, {'created': '2012-06-01 00:04:36.000000000', 'message': "XenAPI: Don't hardcode userdevice for VBDs

Cleanup and refactor the way VBDs are allocated so it's clearer what
userdevice each VDI is allocated to. Also, use a dict of VDIs instead
of a list since it's nonsensical to have multiple VDIs of any type
and simplifies the code somewhat.

Change-Id: I46d6215dbd90822970a874af66f22c9a34529a40
"}]
commit_message:
XenAPI: Don't hardcode userdevice for VBDs

Cleanup and refactor the way VBDs are allocated so it's clearer what
userdevice each VDI is allocated to. Also, use a dict of VDIs instead
of a list since it's nonsensical to have multiple VDIs of any type
and simplifies the code somewhat.

Change-Id: I46d6215dbd90822970a874af66f22c9a34529a40

commit_message:
Use openstack.common.cfg.CONF.

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

This patch makes the rpc code use the global config object from
openstack-common.  Based on some recent discussions on the mailing list,
this may not be the final way configuration handling is done here, but
it is certainly better than the register_opts() hack that is removed by
this patch.

Change-Id: Id128126e0bc064a2a1c710c6bd32fb3d137dc7f6

commit_message:
Create testutils with skip decorators.

This patch creates openstack.common.testutils which includes some
decorators used to conditionally skip tests.  This is needed for the
rpc unit tests.

subject: Added CORS middleware
messages:
[{'account_id': 4150, 'date': '2012-04-30 13:03:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I tested it with a Javascript library, and I implemented the same code in other components without any problem.'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-04-30 16:29:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Can't remember if gerrit fails a build for pep8 stuff now or not but just in case, theres a few pep8 issues:

fhines@ubuntu:~/swift-reviews ((71c9208...))$ pep8 swift/common/middleware/cors.py 
swift/common/middleware/cors.py:87:80: E501 line too long (81 characters)
swift/common/middleware/cors.py:98:50: W291 trailing whitespace
swift/common/middleware/cors.py:98:50: E251 no spaces around keyword / parameter equals
swift/common/middleware/cors.py:143:46: E202 whitespace before '}'
swift/common/middleware/cors.py:148:9: E301 expected 1 blank line, found 0
swift/common/middleware/cors.py:163:1: E302 expected 2 blank lines, found 1"}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-04-30 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Unittests for this break on python 2.6 since you're using assertIn and assertNotIn which aren't present in 2.6."}, {'account_id': 904, 'date': '2012-04-30 20:01:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-01 02:17:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The cors.rst isn't linked to by the main docs best I can tell. Also the link to test-swift-cors.html doesn't seem to be included in the docs build output, resulting in a link to nothing."}, {'account_id': 1049, 'date': '2012-05-01 18:23:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I just finished reading your patch and was hoping we could add in multiple Hosts to respond to. This would allow users to have different configs per hostname allowing more granular access control. Also, this would leave room for Container and Account level CORS headers to be set and would still allow this "Master" CORS middleware to run at the same time. 

For example you have a control panel that uses JavaScript and you want all of your users to be able to upload via XMLHTTP Request. Later on your user base would like to set Custom CORS for Accounts and Containers etc. Having this "Master" CORS middleware would conflict with anything downstream.'}, {'account_id': 904, 'date': '2012-05-01 20:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 904, 'date': '2012-05-01 20:37:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@gholt
I've included the CORS documentation in the source file and linked it to the "Misc" section in the documentation. This is consistent with other middleware components.

I've moved test-swift-cors.html into an external gist. I couldn't find anywhere more appropiate in the Swift repository so this seemed like the least bad option.

@Conrad
Sounds like an interesting addition. I'd like to get this basic middleware approved and merged before I start looking at more specific requirements.'}, {'account_id': 4150, 'date': '2012-05-03 06:39:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-03 18:14:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

For including the html file in the docs, I think you can place the file right where it was in the source dir, but use the literalinclude directive to include it in the doc build:

.. literalinclude:: test-swift-cors.html
    :language: html

But the external link is fine as well.

In the docs, "seperate" should be "separate".

For Conrad's suggestion/concern, it looks like this could easily be expanded to a "database" of CORS settings later, with this current config acting as a fallback (or no fallback if omitted).

Since my "issues" left are all really minor, I'm +2ing this.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-07 19:42:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

Adrian,

With the direction to simplify the core Swift code base and move externalizable (I don't think that's a word, but anyway) parts to separate projects, I think this CORS middleware is perfect for that.

I've separated out my own StaticWeb and TempURL/FormPOST middleware if you want to use those as a basis for the same with CORS:

https://github.com/gholt/swift-staticweb

https://github.com/gholt/swift-tempurl

And then, of course, add CORS links to Swift's doc/source/associated_projects.rst page."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-05-08 21:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

This is to echo what gholt said above.

As a result of https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg11237.html and http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/openstack-meeting/2012/openstack-meeting.2012-05-08-20.00.html, this functionality should be moved into its own repo and managed separately from swift. Therefor I am marking this patch as -2.

This in no way is commenting on the quality of this code (good or bad) or implying anything about its fitness for its intended purpose.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-05-16 21:40:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

sorry for the confusion here, but this has been an active conversation recently

removing my -2 and moving it back to a +0. this may very well be added to swift itself'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-05-23 12:20:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I would like to see this functionality added to swift. However, I don't think middleware is the best place to do it. I think it needs to be added to the proxy server itself.

 - the functionality needs to be multi-tenant aware
 - the proxy already uses and caches container metadata (the logical place for this to live)
 - the object servers already support the ability to add CORS headers to them

All of this means that middleware isn't a good first step. This functionality (as written but with minor changes) should be incorporated into the proxy server.

I would like to help get this functionality added. If you are interested, please email me at me@not.mn or find me on IRC."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-05-28 20:11:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

based on my above review, marking as -1"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-05 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Added CORS middleware

This middleware filter responds to CORS requests from user agents
(http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/). This means Javascript running on one domain can
make requests to another domain hosting Swift. A useful application of this
feature would be a javascript client running entirely within a user's browser.

Change-Id: I447f483b3da24ee34439da404094a427f2b80ce0

commit_message:
Eliminate a race condition on instance deletes.

- Add constraint and equality conditions to nova.db[.sqlalchemy].api
- Use host constraints to ensure the compute api doesn't simply delete
  an instance from the database that a compute manager has already
  started to run.

This race condition is associated with bug #998117

Change-Id: Id74192d3e66bea073327342f57ce0f26987efd2d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-04 21:06:00.000000000', 'message': "Fixed bug where 204 would sometimes be chunked

Not sure how this got introduced (which really annoys me)
but here's the fix to make sure the content-length /
transfer-encoding headers are set properly. Specifically,
the proxy was sometimes returning transfer-encoding: chunked
with no content-length on 204 No Content responses where it
used to return content-length: 0 and no transfer-encoding
header at all.

Fixes LP#1008716

Change-Id: I0927d102bc5e4324e38dbbb44be9033a6cd8ee20
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed bug where 204 would sometimes be chunked

Not sure how this got introduced (which really annoys me)
but here's the fix to make sure the content-length /
transfer-encoding headers are set properly. Specifically,
the proxy was sometimes returning transfer-encoding: chunked
with no content-length on 204 No Content responses where it
used to return content-length: 0 and no transfer-encoding
header at all.

Fixes LP#1008716

Change-Id: I0927d102bc5e4324e38dbbb44be9033a6cd8ee20

Ensure empty results are returned

Make sure that empty but still valid results (like no unmounted drives)
aren't treated as 500 errors.

Fixes LP#1008715

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-04 21:06:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix starvation in object server with fast clients.

When an object server was handling concurrent GET or POST requests
from very fast clients, it would starve other connected clients. The
greenthreads responsible for servicing the fast clients would hog the
processor and only rarely yield to another greenthread.

The reason this happens for GET requests is found in
eventlet.greenio.GreenSocket, in the send() method. When you call
.send(data) on a GreenSocket, it immediately calls .send(data) on its
underlying real socket (socket._socketobject). If the real socket
accepts all the data, then GreenSocket.send() returns without yielding
to another greenthread. Only if the real socket failed to accept all
the data (either .send(data) < len(data) or by raising EWOULDBLOCK)
does the GreenSocket yield control.

Under most workloads, this isn't a problem. The TCP connection to
client X can only consume data so quickly, and therefore the
greenthread serving client X will frequently encounter a full socket
buffer and yield control, so no clients starve. However, when there's
a lot of contention for a single object from a large number of fast
clients (e.g. on a LAN connected w/10Gb Ethernet), then one winds up
in a situation where reading from the disk is slower than writing to
the network, and so full socket buffers become rare, and therefore so
do context switches. The end result is that many clients time out
waiting for data.

The situation for PUT requests is analogous; GreenSocket.recv() seldom
encounters EWOULDBLOCK, so greenthreads seldom yield.

This patch calls eventlet.sleep() to yield control after each chunk,
preventing any one greenthread's IO from blocking the hub for very
long.

This code has the flaw that it will greenthread-switch twice when a
send() or recv() does block, but since there isn't a way to find out
if a switch occurred or not, there's no way to avoid it. Since
greenlet switches are quite fast (faster than system calls, which the
object server does a lot of), this shouldn't have a significant
performance impact.

Fixes LP#1008720

Change-Id: I8549adfb4a198739b80979236c27b76df607eebf
"}]
commit_message:
Fix starvation in object server with fast clients.

When an object server was handling concurrent GET or POST requests
from very fast clients, it would starve other connected clients. The
greenthreads responsible for servicing the fast clients would hog the
processor and only rarely yield to another greenthread.

The reason this happens for GET requests is found in
eventlet.greenio.GreenSocket, in the send() method. When you call
.send(data) on a GreenSocket, it immediately calls .send(data) on its
underlying real socket (socket._socketobject). If the real socket
accepts all the data, then GreenSocket.send() returns without yielding
to another greenthread. Only if the real socket failed to accept all
the data (either .send(data) < len(data) or by raising EWOULDBLOCK)
does the GreenSocket yield control.

Under most workloads, this isn't a problem. The TCP connection to
client X can only consume data so quickly, and therefore the
greenthread serving client X will frequently encounter a full socket
buffer and yield control, so no clients starve. However, when there's
a lot of contention for a single object from a large number of fast
clients (e.g. on a LAN connected w/10Gb Ethernet), then one winds up
in a situation where reading from the disk is slower than writing to
the network, and so full socket buffers become rare, and therefore so
do context switches. The end result is that many clients time out
waiting for data.

The situation for PUT requests is analogous; GreenSocket.recv() seldom
encounters EWOULDBLOCK, so greenthreads seldom yield.

This patch calls eventlet.sleep() to yield control after each chunk,
preventing any one greenthread's IO from blocking the hub for very
long.

This code has the flaw that it will greenthread-switch twice when a
send() or recv() does block, but since there isn't a way to find out
if a switch occurred or not, there's no way to avoid it. Since
greenlet switches are quite fast (faster than system calls, which the
object server does a lot of), this shouldn't have a significant
performance impact.

Fixes LP#1008720

Change-Id: I8549adfb4a198739b80979236c27b76df607eebf

respectively.  They also have independent glue code
(glance/api/policy.py and nova/policy.py), so that the common
policy system is substantially similar.  This makes policies a
perfect candidate for incorporation into openstack-common,
particularly given that this same code will soon be used by

interface changes and bug fixes) to openstack-common, along with
a test suite.

Change-Id: I0022a91f16ded28f9dc6b4975ef1b6e4cc8460ac
'}]
commit_message:
Common-ize policies.

Both Glance and Nova make use of (almost) the same policy system,
defined in glance/common/policy.py and nova/common/policy.py,
respectively.  They also have independent glue code
(glance/api/policy.py and nova/policy.py), so that the common
policy system is substantially similar.  This makes policies a
perfect candidate for incorporation into openstack-common,
particularly given that this same code will soon be used by
Quantum.

This change adds the common policy module (along with some minor
interface changes and bug fixes) to openstack-common, along with
a test suite.

Change-Id: I0022a91f16ded28f9dc6b4975ef1b6e4cc8460ac

commit_message:
convert virt drivers to fully dynamic loading

Progress on bp:virt-driver-cleanup

This series of patches converts the virt drivers to loading via
importutils making it possible to add a virt driver without changing
core code. It deprecates the use of connection_type in favor of a
full driver name in compute_driver.

Based on email thread with Vish and Jay Pipes on approaches to do
this.

Change-Id: I48366ec7efc7b095859988e5e6ac5a853b98b8a7

commit_message:
only allow methods which implement HTTP verbs to be called remotely

This fixes 500 server crashes caused by requests such as:

curl -X__init__ "http://your-swift-object-server:6000/sda1/p/a/c/o"

Fixes bug 1005903

Change-Id: I6c0ad39a29e07ce5f46b0fdbd11a53a9a1010a04

commit_message:
Add missing import to quantum manager.

This patch adds a missing import of rpc to the quantum manager.  rpc
usage was added in d901b44fea897a038ce9a8afa32751ab79ffa210, but the
import was never there.

Change-Id: Id98a7034d190338c48d7e8c787b3d152cafe6353

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-01 19:01:05.000000000', 'message': 'Add a comment to rpc.queue_get_for().

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

Add a comment to the rpc.queue_get_for() function that notes that this
is simply a naming convention and is dependent on how queues are set up
on the consumer side.

Change-Id: Ifa7d648e9b33ad2416236dc6966527c257baaf88
'}]
commit_message:
Add a comment to rpc.queue_get_for().

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

Add a comment to the rpc.queue_get_for() function that notes that this
is simply a naming convention and is dependent on how queues are set up
on the consumer side.

Change-Id: Ifa7d648e9b33ad2416236dc6966527c257baaf88

'}, {'account_id': 4120, 'date': '2012-05-30 15:48:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi Jay,

I edited the patch set to contain only negative tests, and left out the positive tests for another branch.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 4120, 'date': '2012-05-30 15:51:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-30 20:26:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

tests look good.'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-05-31 04:49:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Just one minor nit for clarity"}, {'account_id': 4120, 'date': '2012-05-31 06:09:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-06-01 13:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Rohit, your last comment said the test would be skipped until the bug is fixed, but the code was not changed to skip. I think we decided last month that we would not intentionally put code in tempest that would break when a bug was fixed.'}, {'account_id': 4120, 'date': '2012-06-01 14:50:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 4120, 'date': '2012-06-01 14:53:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi David, 
The reply comments published should have been followed by a patch set. I guess I missed that, I uploaded a patch set now that contains skip decorator with the corresponding Bug and modified the assertion to expect what is actually expected (BadRequest) for the scenario. So once the bug is fixed and the test un-skipped, the test should not fail.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-06-04 17:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

subject: Ensure Quantum activated with Tempest
messages:
[{'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-06-04 17:11:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

There is an outstanding change to start using quantum in
the normal (non-tempest) version of the devstack gate.

It hasn't been able to land yet, so this patch is virtually guaranteed not to work.

If you or someone else has time to work on this, I think we should work on getting quantum added to the normal version of devstack gate (which will, in turn, also cause it to be used in the tempest version).

Here's the other change:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6641/"}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-06-04 17:11:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-04 17:11:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-devstack-gate-merge/80/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-04 17:11:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

OK, no worries. Looking at the other change, looks like it will indeed solve the issue properly.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-04 17:11:53.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure Quantum activated with Tempest

Tempest now includes Quantum tests, so make sure
Quantum is activated in devstack service list when
Tempest is being called.

Change-Id: I3a37541e798a3fc7ff51428a176529d79dc00f4d
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure Quantum activated with Tempest

Tempest now includes Quantum tests, so make sure
Quantum is activated in devstack service list when
Tempest is being called.

Change-Id: I3a37541e798a3fc7ff51428a176529d79dc00f4d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-04 16:10:57.000000000', 'message': 'separate Metadata logic away from the web service

The changes here are coming as a result of starting to implement
config-drive-v2 [1].  I wanted to separate out the "Metadata" from the
"Metadata Server".  Thus, the creation of nova/api/metadata/base.py.

The InstanceMetadata in base.py contains most of the logic for
presenting metadata.  As a result, the Metadata webservice in handler.py
greatly simplified.  This should make it easier to render duplicate
data to a config drive.

Additional changes here:
 * a few more tests
 * removal of the separate 'Versions' handler.  Its now replaced
   by the single handler.

--
[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/config-drive-v2

Change-Id: I35fcfd8d7f247763954afc0a9f752f629b243e9b

remove debug code

Change-Id: Ie781221ded2029c763fbc0529f50988a201aa816
'}]
commit_message:
separate Metadata logic away from the web service

The changes here are coming as a result of starting to implement
config-drive-v2 [1].  I wanted to separate out the "Metadata" from the
"Metadata Server".  Thus, the creation of nova/api/metadata/base.py.

The InstanceMetadata in base.py contains most of the logic for
presenting metadata.  As a result, the Metadata webservice in handler.py
greatly simplified.  This should make it easier to render duplicate
data to a config drive.

Additional changes here:
 * a few more tests
 * removal of the separate 'Versions' handler.  Its now replaced
   by the single handler.

--
[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/config-drive-v2

Change-Id: I35fcfd8d7f247763954afc0a9f752f629b243e9b

remove debug code

Change-Id: Ie781221ded2029c763fbc0529f50988a201aa816

commit_message:
Add minimal support for the v2 API

This only allows you to run image-list, but sets up a framework
that we can use to fill in the rest of the v2 functionality.

* Related to bp glance-client-v2

Change-Id: I8827e36fdcf79fe402990a6d05898ec00cbd54c6

commit_message:
Don't deepcopy RpcContext

Instead of deepcopying the RpcContext, which seems to not work
sometimes, we'll explicitly create a new instance of the class and
deepcopy the required values.

Fixes bug 1007043

Change-Id: I6578c4c82046acf149724a1c5985fa6b46857a7c

subject: Changing tox.ini to specify pep8==0.6.1
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-merge/4/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-pep8/4/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-python26/4/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-quantum-python27/4/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If we don't specify the exact version in either place, then the local test-requires and the remote in jenkins will always be checking with the latest version."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Running `tox -r` will regenerate the virtualenv, causing an update to all the packages.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

We should always use the latest version of pep8."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

let's talk a bit more before deciding whether we want to hardcode pep8 verisons or not.  Either way, test-requires and tox.ini should take the same approach (currently, test-requires hardcodes, tox.ini does not)"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

perhaps this comes down to whether you're running with a clean tox environment each time?  in my experience, pip wil not download a new version of pep8 if the only requirement is "pep8".

that said, I've already spent more time conversing on this than its worth, so I give up.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

hehe, looks like we're having this discussion on two reviews.

We should use the same pep8 as other openstack projects.  I'm fine with this being 1.1, but people should be in sync, rather than have things break randomly when jenkins suddenly pulls down a new pep8 package."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

btw, I'm definitely fine with fixing the python code either way... 

To me the issue is more about ensuring consistency between the test-requires and what tox uses for gating."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Makes more sense to just clean up the pep8 errors, no?"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-04 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

we're still talking about the right way to handle this, and it will likely involve no longer hard-coding pep8 version at all."}]

commit_message:
Changing tox.ini to specify pep8==0.6.1

This is required so that CI infrastructure used to gate all quantum merges
uses the same pep8 version as we have in our tools/pip-requires.

Change-Id: I34862c135b8ba286d1065be9a5400e4c0b04a0c8

commit_message:
Updated image example to cirros, add boot section

Updated the section on uploading images to use the newer CirrOS images rather
than the old ttylinux image.

Added a section on booting an instance from the command-line.

Removed images-uploading.xml since it seems to be unused.

messages:

Nice - one minor question I'd be interested in your feedback on, but otherwise good to go from me :D"}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-06-03 03:59:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-06-03 04:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-06-03 04:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Tom: I'm not sure of a general way to check for the presence of dhcp_release across distributions. On Ubuntu, it's in /usr/bin so you can use the "which" command and it'll find it since it's in the default PATH. It's possible that on other distributions it's not in the default PATH for a regular user (e.g. /sbin or /usr/sbin on some distributions). So I put a tip in to check as root.'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-06-03 07:11:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

subject: DRYing up Essex migration.
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-15 21:41:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I like the idea of DRY'ing up the timestamps data.

I'm not sure there is value in changing the 'utf8' code. Additionally my preference would be to leave the ID data inline with the tables as well...

Also, Just curious... have you tested this w/ Postgres and MySQL?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-15 22:04:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I like the idea of DRY'ing up the timestamps data.

Agreed that it's the clearest win.

> I'm not sure there is value in changing the 'utf8' code.

Looking through your comments in the file, it looked like the long-term goal was to get to a point where utf8 would be declared inline for all tables.

The idea with including the utf8 refactoring was to prepare for that future work. `cells` already does this, but once all of the other tables conform, we can remove lots of extraneous code and it will all be replaced with that single line in `_prepare_tables`.

It parallels what we have to do with setting the `mysql_engine`, so I thought i made sense to just apply those configs at the same time.

> Additionally my preference would be to leave the ID data inline with the tables as well...

I went back-and-forth on this. On one hand, since ID columns slightly differ between tables, it's just 'easier' to declare it with each table.

On the other, the overwhelming number of tables use the same ID column type (integer); we have just a few exceptions. So the idea was to reduce lines of code as well as highlight--rather than bury in a myriad of table definitions--the few inconsistencies we do have.

Both arguments have points, I suppose, so, could really go either way.

> Also, Just curious... have you tested this w/ Postgres and MySQL?

Just with MySQL so far."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-15 23:07:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

one of the early migrations set utf8 as the default on the database, so as long as the combined migration didn't clobber that, it shouldn't be necessary to set it on all of the tables."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-16 06:14:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-16 06:18:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The update to the patch adds a doc-string to explain why per-table UTF-8 is still needed (until Folsom and Essex are compacted together).

The latest version also refactors the code so only the tables that need foreign-key checking turned off, use it; the rest use in-line UTF-8.

Working on testing this w/ postgres, but working through various setup issues hampering that effort.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-16 07:20:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-16 07:21:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Latest version fixes the broken test. It was relying on implicit ordering (which was unsafe). The reordering of the columns exposed this hidden assumption. The solution was to use explicit id ordering in the `rules` backref.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-16 19:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hey Rick.

Couple of things I wanted to mention about the 082_essex.py migration. When I created it the most important thing to me was making sure that it produces *exactly* the same schema for MySQL and PostgreSQL that the old Essex migrations did... in a more compact fashion. There is quite a bit of refactoring I didn't do because of this. Things like fkey names, etc. are tricky to get right across all the databases when doing the compaction due to the way some of the initial migrations were written.

I wrote up a wiki on how I approached the testing...

  http://wiki.openstack.org/database_migration_testing

I suppose some of the changes you propose here look safer than others. Factoring out the timestamps to DRY things up looks pretty safe for example. As for the other changes I'd certainly want to run though these tests again to make sure things are exactly the same.

Given there aren't automated tests to make sure we get this right it will be on us to go through the process again every time we refactor 082. Honestly we really need some automated "upgrade" tests anyway so perhaps testing our compacted database migrations would fit into an upgrade tests framework somewhere?

Just wanted to make sure we are on the same page as far as testing, goals, etc.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-16 19:56:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Dan:

Excellent point about automating the compaction validation.

I agree, we pretty much need that for this patch to move forward.

I'll start investigating how we can do that.

It probably won't end up looking like a true unit-test (because it crosses multiple branches), but will probably something in the `tools` directory.

Perhaps something like:

./tools/db/validate_migrate_compaction.py <compacted migration number>"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-16 20:01:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Well... FWIW I *should* have written a test tool for this too. The initial migration compaction took much longer than I initially anticipated however so I never got to it.

Also, I didn't realize we'd be raising the bar on a bi-weekly basis ;)"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-16 22:38:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Dan:

Heh, I was skeptical of the compaction, but now that I've seen the results I'm totally on board with doing this every release.

We end up with a readable schema (like Rails schema.rb), so we can identify and solve all sorts of consistency issues.

The other thing I'm looking forward to, is perhaps using this as a jump-off point for moving from sqlalchemy-migrate (old and busted!) to Alembic (the new hotness)."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-17 01:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

WIP'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:13:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

nice work so far. adding to radar'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-02 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
DRYing up Essex migration.

Factors out columns and settings common to all tables so that table
definitions are more concise. Also, uses a declarative-style to capture
inconsistencies between table definitions.

Change-Id: I00052666a8844b3f8b5d2f771a8ede4b28a9c086

commit_message:
Validate metadata in fake image

When uploading an image to Glance, the metadata are validated. But the fake
image service doesn't do that, therefore it says that things are OK where
they're not, and the image will be refused by Glance.

So this patch validates image using Glance function validate_image and fixes
tests that fail due to this change.

This fixes bug #973314

Change-Id: I3b4c1c4e6000420442363683983843efb933f9d0
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-01 22:27:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix starvation in object server with fast clients.

When an object server was handling concurrent GET or POST requests
from very fast clients, it would starve other connected clients. The
greenthreads responsible for servicing the fast clients would hog the
processor and only rarely yield to another greenthread.

The reason this happens for GET requests is found in
eventlet.greenio.GreenSocket, in the send() method. When you call
.send(data) on a GreenSocket, it immediately calls .send(data) on its
underlying real socket (socket._socketobject). If the real socket
accepts all the data, then GreenSocket.send() returns without yielding
to another greenthread. Only if the real socket failed to accept all
the data (either .send(data) < len(data) or by raising EWOULDBLOCK)
does the GreenSocket yield control.

Under most workloads, this isn't a problem. The TCP connection to
client X can only consume data so quickly, and therefore the
greenthread serving client X will frequently encounter a full socket
buffer and yield control, so no clients starve. However, when there's
a lot of contention for a single object from a large number of fast
clients (e.g. on a LAN connected w/10Gb Ethernet), then one winds up
in a situation where reading from the disk is slower than writing to
the network, and so full socket buffers become rare, and therefore so
do context switches. The end result is that many clients time out
waiting for data.

The situation for PUT requests is analogous; GreenSocket.recv() seldom
encounters EWOULDBLOCK, so greenthreads seldom yield.

This patch calls eventlet.sleep() to yield control after each chunk,
preventing any one greenthread's IO from blocking the hub for very
long.

This code has the flaw that it will greenthread-switch twice when a
send() or recv() does block, but since there isn't a way to find out
if a switch occurred or not, there's no way to avoid it. Since
greenlet switches are quite fast (faster than system calls, which the
object server does a lot of), this shouldn't have a significant
performance impact.

Change-Id: I8549adfb4a198739b80979236c27b76df607eebf
"}]
commit_message:
Fix starvation in object server with fast clients.

When an object server was handling concurrent GET or POST requests
from very fast clients, it would starve other connected clients. The
greenthreads responsible for servicing the fast clients would hog the
processor and only rarely yield to another greenthread.

The reason this happens for GET requests is found in
eventlet.greenio.GreenSocket, in the send() method. When you call
.send(data) on a GreenSocket, it immediately calls .send(data) on its
underlying real socket (socket._socketobject). If the real socket
accepts all the data, then GreenSocket.send() returns without yielding
to another greenthread. Only if the real socket failed to accept all
the data (either .send(data) < len(data) or by raising EWOULDBLOCK)
does the GreenSocket yield control.

Under most workloads, this isn't a problem. The TCP connection to
client X can only consume data so quickly, and therefore the
greenthread serving client X will frequently encounter a full socket
buffer and yield control, so no clients starve. However, when there's
a lot of contention for a single object from a large number of fast
clients (e.g. on a LAN connected w/10Gb Ethernet), then one winds up
in a situation where reading from the disk is slower than writing to
the network, and so full socket buffers become rare, and therefore so
do context switches. The end result is that many clients time out
waiting for data.

The situation for PUT requests is analogous; GreenSocket.recv() seldom
encounters EWOULDBLOCK, so greenthreads seldom yield.

This patch calls eventlet.sleep() to yield control after each chunk,
preventing any one greenthread's IO from blocking the hub for very
long.

This code has the flaw that it will greenthread-switch twice when a
send() or recv() does block, but since there isn't a way to find out
if a switch occurred or not, there's no way to avoid it. Since
greenlet switches are quite fast (faster than system calls, which the
object server does a lot of), this shouldn't have a significant
performance impact.

Change-Id: I8549adfb4a198739b80979236c27b76df607eebf

subject: Proxy logging content-length fix
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-01 16:02:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-swift-pep8/23/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-swift-python27/24/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-swift-python26/23/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-swift-merge/23/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-01 16:13:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yesterday I couldn't track down the 204 with transfer-encoding: chunked bug's source quickly enough, so I just submitted a fix for the symptom I saw.

But, this morning I finally tracked down the source. If a response contains no content-length and no transfer-encoding, Eventlet will check if the body implements len. If it does, Eventlet will sum up the lens and tack on a content-length itself.

Because proxy-logging is now wrapping the response, Eventlet doesn't ever see a len implementation and so never tacks on content-length anymore.

In particular, this screws up 204s from the proxy server, but it probably affects other responses not yet noticed.

So, that's what this fix is about, essentially having proxy-logging do what Eventlet would.

Note: I'm not 100% happy with this because it iterates the iterable to compute the length and the iterable might not be resettable. Also, if the iterable is freakin' huge this len computation is probably a waste of time when transfer-encoding: chunked should've been used. But, since this is what Eventlet does anyway, and damnit, responses should set either content-length or transfer-encoding themselves anyway... We should probably just move on."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-06-01 17:23:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

204 responses shouldn't have a content-length or transfer-encoding.  I don't like this too much, but until we can fix the eventlet server, it at least works :)"}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-06-01 17:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

what john's going to say"}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-06-01 17:49:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

now start_response() isn't called until the iter_response() is actually yielding values. this is a problem"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-01 18:52:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh my, unless I'm now the one confused it sounds like I have to explain all this again. :)

>>>

PEP 333:

Note: the application must invoke the start_response() callable before the iterable yields its first body string, so that the server can send the headers before any body content. However, this invocation may be performed by the iterable's first iteration, so servers must not assume that start_response() has been called before they begin iterating over the iterable.

>>>"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-01 18:54:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah dangit, I think I see what you mean now. I was the one confused. :)'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-01 19:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-01 19:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-swift-python26/26/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-swift-merge/26/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-06-01 19:58:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtmwtfbbq'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-01 21:43:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

messages:
[{'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-05-22 17:37:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think it would be good to get essex stable working with the new style of XenServer install.

I want to get some qa running with XenServer and essex stable, and this change would be a big help.

Really just pushing this to gain an initial yes/no for the idea.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-05-29 14:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-05-29 22:57:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Actually, looking at this more closely, I found that in stack.sh for Essex stable, the expression to look for the network bridge looks like this one:

FLAT_NETWORK_BRIDGE_DEFAULT=$(grep -o 'flat_network_bridge=[^.]*' /proc/cmdline | cut -d= -f 2)

whereas, on trunk, it looks like this one:

FLAT_NETWORK_BRIDGE_DEFAULT=$(grep -o 'flat_network_bridge=[[:alnum:]]*' /proc/cmdline | cut -d= -f 2 | sort -u)

For some strange reason, my pvargs always show two flat_network_bridge flags, so the first one won't work. So you've got to update stack.sh too."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-05-30 08:25:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Renuka spent some time trying to track down what that was. I think it is because those args are copied by the installer into grub, then supplied again on the following boots, but haven't confirmed that or tried to fix it.

I can add that change in. In my system I want it to work cross machine, so I just specify the bridge name, so I didn't see this - oops."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-05-30 08:33:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-05-30 22:58:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

- allow you to configure the xenapi_user (often other than root)
- allow you to disable the guest installer network
- install the plugins in the xcp-xapi location
- use alternate webserver location when adding the preseed file
- skip the centos specific ip forwarding configuration
- make use xcp inventory, if no xensource-inventory is found
- correctly deal with kpartx to mount the VM VDI in manage_vdi

Change-Id: I8d51725fc97f0bcaa27a46f7a7ced13c369c809e
'}]
commit_message:
Make devstack work with xcp-xapi package on Ubuntu 12.04

- allow you to configure the xenapi_user (often other than root)
- allow you to disable the guest installer network
- install the plugins in the xcp-xapi location
- use alternate webserver location when adding the preseed file
- skip the centos specific ip forwarding configuration
- make use xcp inventory, if no xensource-inventory is found
- correctly deal with kpartx to mount the VM VDI in manage_vdi

Change-Id: I8d51725fc97f0bcaa27a46f7a7ced13c369c809e

commit_message:
Improvements to DevStack's XenServer scripts

I have ensured:
- template gets re-used on second run
- template includes XenServer tools, and custom user accounts
- take snapshot before first boot, for easy re-run
- make host_ip_iface work with either eth2 or eth3
- make ssh into domU checks looser
- above is all ground work for improved jenkins tests
- added some more comments to make it scripts clearer

Change-Id: I5c45370bf8a1393d669480e196b13f592d29154f

commit_message:
Add additional info. to image.delete notification

Add additional information to the 'image.delete' notification payload
to simplify external usage tracking systems.

Please note that this is not a backwards-compatible change as the
old payload was simply a string consisting of the image id.  This
converts the payload to a dictionary.

Change-Id: I641b7de91fcc14dc3c81ec942aeb0acf5a63d128

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-30 21:18:00.000000000', 'message': 'Fix instance update notification publisher id

Fixes instance update notifications to follow the nova convention for
publisher ids.  The notification publisher id will now be of the format
service.host (e.g. compute.somehostname).

Change-Id: Ib5c4c962b9ac3e0bac90703b20465f99dfd047c0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix instance update notification publisher id

Fixes instance update notifications to follow the nova convention for
publisher ids.  The notification publisher id will now be of the format
service.host (e.g. compute.somehostname).

Change-Id: Ib5c4c962b9ac3e0bac90703b20465f99dfd047c0

commit_message:
Use compute rpcapi in nova-manage.

Part of bug 1006467.

This patch fixes nova-manage to use the compute rpcapi instead of
calling rpc.cast() directly.  This cast was actually broken, as it sent
an instance ID instead of UUID, so this change should make this code
functional again.

Change-Id: I90a1bf4a03cc6d9e21f24f19165141f894b6ec75

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-31 23:01:11.000000000', 'message': "Fixed bug where 204 would sometimes be chunked

Not sure how this got introduced (which really annoys me)
but here's the fix to make sure the content-length /
transfer-encoding headers are set properly. Specifically,
the proxy was sometimes returning transfer-encoding: chunked
with no content-length on 204 No Content responses where it
used to return content-length: 0 and no transfer-encoding
header at all.

Change-Id: I0927d102bc5e4324e38dbbb44be9033a6cd8ee20
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed bug where 204 would sometimes be chunked

Not sure how this got introduced (which really annoys me)
but here's the fix to make sure the content-length /
transfer-encoding headers are set properly. Specifically,
the proxy was sometimes returning transfer-encoding: chunked
with no content-length on 204 No Content responses where it
used to return content-length: 0 and no transfer-encoding
header at all.

Change-Id: I0927d102bc5e4324e38dbbb44be9033a6cd8ee20

commit_message:
Ensure empty results are returned

Make sure that empty but still valid results (like no unmounted drives)
aren't treated as 500 errors.

Change-Id: I9588e2711d7916406f15613d5a26b9f0cf38235a

commit_message:
Add finish_revert_resize() to the compute rpcapi.

Part of bug 1006467.

This method is used by the compute manager itself.  Add it to the
rpcapi and use it from there.

Change-Id: I7fcab5b0b498318377a1a108e2eeb4db1ae1e4ea

rpcapi.  This is used by the console manager.

commit_message:
Report memory correctly on Xen. Fixes bug 997014

/proc/meminfo may show wrong values for the memory when using Xen, so
this correctly computes the memory by querying libvirt.

Change-Id: I188e2d34bcee13954653b93b9b816cf4530b8859

commit_message:
Fix Multi_Scheduler to process host capabilities

To fix bug #1000403, make sure that each driver held by the
Multi Scheduler gets called during update_service_capabilities.

Change-Id: If8a942317b9b26dd101c5bcf502aab7296608abd

commit_message:
Nail pep8 dependencies to 1.0.1.

Nails the pep8 deps for tox and test-requires to 1.0.1.
Fixes an issues causing pep8 failures due to a new pep8 release.

(cherry picked from commit e3d7d3a)

Change-Id: I30be4909f052c29834afbfddba6007045afa519b

subject: Support create/delete floating ip pools in os-floating-ip-pools api
messages:
[{'account_id': 1935, 'date': '2012-05-13 13:53:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is originally proposed at https://review.openstack.org/4500 for Essex in the last minute and didn't get in. Now resubmitted for Folsom."}, {'account_id': 1935, 'date': '2012-05-13 13:59:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Although I resubmitted this patch all most as is, I'm wondering how floating ip is managed in Folsom. In Essex Design Summit, I leaned that Quantum is going to have more broad functionality including IPAM. So, the capabilities of this patch should also go to Quantum?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-13 16:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Tomoe, you may also want to look into the Melange project, which implements IPAM for OpenStack:

https://github.com/openstack/melange

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-13 16:45:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

Some small things inline, but the biggest issue I see with this code is that it breaks the API standards that OpenStack REST APIs have used so far for DELETE calls. By using a UUID primary key for a floating IP pool, it would be easier to implement in the same was as any other OpenStack Compute API extension using calls like this:

 DELETE /os-floating-ip-pools/<UUID>

Instead of what you do in this patch:

 DELETE /os-floating-ip-pools/delete_ip_range

with a body containing this:

{'floating_ip_pool': {'ip_range': <IP_RANGE>}}

See inline comments for a more in-depth discussion"}, {'account_id': 1935, 'date': '2012-05-13 23:54:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Jay for your review.
Yes, I agree that the DELETE is a bit of hack. Would be better to have uuid for the pool, however the DB is now denormalized, i.e. there's no floating ip pools table. 
Anyway, I'll take a closer look at your comment and also melange project.

Thanks!
Tomoe"}, {'account_id': 1935, 'date': '2012-05-15 23:27:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

OK, to improve things incrementally, I'd like to let this in first before considering melange. 

Jay,
Would you agree that we should have a table for pool to have uuid field and normalize tables? In other words, we'll have a separate table for pools, floating_ip_pools, and entries in floating ip table have a foreign key constraints on pool id.

Tomoe"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-15 23:34:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Considering this is just an extension for nova to get us by until melange supports this and it lets us stop using a nova-manage command, I think the weird rest syntax is acceptable.'}, {'account_id': 1935, 'date': '2012-05-19 13:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If this change is acceptable, I can submit another patch with a fix for the pep8 violation.'}, {'account_id': 1935, 'date': '2012-05-24 12:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

ping?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-24 20:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Yeah, agreed with Vish.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-01 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-01 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-01 07:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Please bring this back!'}]

subject: Add sqlalchemy pool_size flag
messages:
[{'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-16 07:57:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-16 12:07:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This was removed by I9b1f4790fcdb890a5113b853f1b1483f3212c530

Need to understand why it was removed and why we need with adding it back again"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-16 12:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hey, Mark.

I wrote some stress-test scripts to find out how many queries the nova.db.sqlalchemy driver is capable of. Since the default size is 5 and max_overflow 10, the stress test halts after about 15 tests.

I did a quick patch for our Essex production deployment and thought that this should go in on Folsom.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-23 02:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-23 02:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Am I the only one with db connection problems in a production deployment?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-23 20:58:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I personally would like to see this patch go through. Zhongyue, would you mind paste-binning your test code that shows the bottleneck that this patch gets around? If I can run it on some test clusters that show the scaling/throughput improvement, maybe we can push this merge proposal forward...'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-23 23:58:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Jay I'll post it on bin paste once we review the code internally."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-24 07:27:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Someone just needs to explain why this won't re-introduce bug #838581

e.g. is it because this patch uses sqlalchemy.pool.QueuePool rather than eventlet.db_pool.ConnectionPool ? If so, explain why the former works where the latter didn't"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-01 06:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-01 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Build Successful

It's best to avoid quotes.

I was wondering about supporting leading spaces, but that's problematic with ini files so some other replacement mechanism would be best for that if ever needed.

For example with iniparse the values returned for:

    [blah]
    a=b
    c = d
    e= f
    g=  h
    i="j"

are:

    b
    d
    f
    h
    "j"

so lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-30 22:17:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

subject: Backslash continuation removal (Nova folsom-2)
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 1994, 'name': 'Zhongyue Luo', 'email': 'zhongyue.luo@gmail.com', 'username': 'zyluo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2340, 'name': 'Ionut Artarisi', 'email': 'iartarisi@suse.cz', 'username': 'mapleoin'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-17 08:05:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-17 08:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-17 08:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-17 11:17:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-17 16:24:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This patch includes a number of formatting changes beyond removal of backslash continuations.  I would prefer minimizing unnecessary changes to minimize potential conflicts."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-05-17 17:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I don't see anything in HACKING.rst about not using backslash continuations.  If we want to forbid them shouldn't this be added to HACKING.rst?"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-18 01:19:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Russell: I'll remove the unrelated parts and do them in another patch.

Joe: If you look at the "Maximum Line Length" section in pep8,

"Long lines can be broken over multiple lines by wrapping expressions in parentheses. These should be used in preference to using a backslash for line continuation."'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-18 01:43:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-05-18 02:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Zhongyue, pep8 only *recommends* to not use a backslash continuation and the pep8 checker (which we gate on) does not look for them.  So I still stand by if we want to forbid them, we should add them to HACKING.rst.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-18 02:17:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Joe, I'll file a bug report to update HACKING.rst."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-05-23 14:27:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Russell I removed the formatting changes from the last patch.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-23 18:56:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Fix destination host for remove_volume_connection.

This patch fixes a regression in
957c4ff741b4029cf4bad5087000fba91f0ce938.  The destination host was
accidentally changed to 'host' when it should have been 'dest'.

Change-Id: I2b262c4aedc2caa0c98c7660853358fc59935b63

commit_message:
README.rst: remove references to mvn invocations in doc/

The doc/ directory has no pom.xml, thus "mvn clean generate-sources"
can't work from there. Remove the reference.

Change-Id: Ie85ae010e74aa918e29a8f7aaa1f61011ff43285

[{'created': '2012-05-31 17:43:00.000000000', 'message': 'Cleans up extraneous volume_api calls

 * Partially implements blueprint volume-decoupling
 * Deletes update() which should not be public
 * Removes extra call to update() in rollback live migration that
   was missed in an earlier patch
 * Deletes remove_from_compute() in preference to compute doing
   the call to the destination host directly
 * Removes wait_creation and moves the polling to the one place
   it is used

Change-Id: I63160e0fd048f82937a322bd068c3a9ff4f60336
'}]
commit_message:
Cleans up extraneous volume_api calls

 * Partially implements blueprint volume-decoupling
 * Deletes update() which should not be public
 * Removes extra call to update() in rollback live migration that
   was missed in an earlier patch
 * Deletes remove_from_compute() in preference to compute doing
   the call to the destination host directly
 * Removes wait_creation and moves the polling to the one place
   it is used

Change-Id: I63160e0fd048f82937a322bd068c3a9ff4f60336

Prevent task_state changes during VERIFY_RESIZE.

Don't allow operations that cause task_state to change
when an instance is in VERIFY_RESIZE.

Fixes LP Bug #965630.

[{'created': '2012-05-31 13:16:02.000000000', 'message': "Make sure an exception is logged when config file isn't found

Fixes bug 1006457

Since exception.ConfigNotFound was derived from exception.NotFound, it
would result in a silent 404 error being returned to the client instead
of logging a useful error message that a necessary config file was
missing and returning a 500 error.

Change-Id: I3abefae8d41be4013501ba1731fa49e3c93bde1a
"}]
commit_message:
Make sure an exception is logged when config file isn't found

Fixes bug 1006457

Since exception.ConfigNotFound was derived from exception.NotFound, it
would result in a silent 404 error being returned to the client instead
of logging a useful error message that a necessary config file was
missing and returning a 500 error.

Change-Id: I3abefae8d41be4013501ba1731fa49e3c93bde1a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-24 11:05:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add a note on why quota classes are unused in Nova

Quota classes can only be used if you write a custom middleware which
sets the quota_class context attribute. Nothing in OpenStack core does
this.

The only known middleware which does this is the rs_limits turnstile
preprocessor: https://github.com/klmitch/rs_limits

Add a note to the code to give others some chance of figuring this out
for themselves.

Change-Id: I52973f2f4d7f07f5121492e062dd31cadf02aa43
'}, {'created': '2012-05-30 22:20:10.000000000', 'message': 'Add a note on why quota classes are unused in Nova

Quota classes can only be used if you write a custom middleware which
sets the quota_class context attribute. Nothing in OpenStack core does
this.

The only known middleware which does this is the rs_limits turnstile
preprocessor: https://github.com/klmitch/rs_limits

Add a note to the code to give others some chance of figuring this out
for themselves.

Change-Id: I52973f2f4d7f07f5121492e062dd31cadf02aa43
'}]
commit_message:
Add a note on why quota classes are unused in Nova

Quota classes can only be used if you write a custom middleware which
sets the quota_class context attribute. Nothing in OpenStack core does
this.

The only known middleware which does this is the rs_limits turnstile
preprocessor: https://github.com/klmitch/rs_limits

Add a note to the code to give others some chance of figuring this out
for themselves.

Change-Id: I52973f2f4d7f07f5121492e062dd31cadf02aa43

messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-29 08:06:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is patch 2 of 6 in the cfg-global-object series'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-29 08:11:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-pep8/8/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-merge/8/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python26/8/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python27/8/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-29 18:01:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I strongly question the idea that its good for all of our test cases to share code through a base class.

I generally find that DRYing up code through base class abstraction isn't a sustainable practice. And in python, it doesn't even save code since you have to spend a line calling super(). You could use that line to aggregate the behavior you want to share.

But that's all just philosophy. There is one blocking comment inline."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-29 18:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-29 18:57:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The main thing I want in the base class is the config() method for overriding config option values and then to use tearDown() to unset those overrides

I figure since so many tests use stubout, it makes sense to setup and teardown those in the one place too'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-29 19:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Add a base class for tests

This base class will allow us to DRY up the config setup and teardown.

I will admit that I'm a bit picky when it comes to using decorators. However, can you share your reasoning why you chose to use decorators here rather than a traditional function call?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-29 18:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Mark,

In my view decorators are a useful mechanism to weave in cross-cutting concerns in a declarative way - i.e. I can declare a method to be mutating without interrupting the logical flow of code with the functional equivalent.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-29 20:55:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I think this is actually a great use of decorators. It's abstracting out a common piece of functionality that doesn't actually change the flow of the function it is decorating. It's really just 'flavoring' the function.

Could you link this branch to the 'api-2' blueprint?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:08:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:23:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me
