(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:58:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:59:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-pep8/25/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-merge/25/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python26/25/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python27/25/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-05-30 04:28:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Eoghan,

I see where you're coming from with decorators. I just find (especially in my experience with nova code) that decorators often come with some hidden costs that might be better avoided.

In this case, the utility decorator is actually fairly situational. It can only be applied to functions that take a request object as their second argument.

In addition, decorators are always statically composed with the functions they modify. That means it is often very hard to get context-specific data into them. It can be done, but it involves bending over backwards or breaking encapsulation. Requiring context to be in a certain place in the function signature is a good example of breaking encapsulation. For the awkward acrobatics, have a look at how utils.synchronized is used in nova's nova/compute/manager.py for the run_instance function.

Finally, while one or two decorators is usually seen as fine, people usually don't like seeing 4 or more decorators on a function. On the otherhand, it's not much of a style problem to add 4 lines to a function. So in that sense its not a particularly sustainable practice.

For those reasons, it just seems like

def some_mutating_function(request, ...)
    request.context.assert_readonly()
    ...

would be more advisable.

In my view, decorators are an attractive nuisance. But I understand I'm in probably in the minority. So I'll thank you for considering my argument and quiet down for a while :-)"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-30 09:22:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-30 09:24:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

@bcwaldon

Module import now restored.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-30 09:31:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-pep8/27/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-merge/27/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python26/27/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-glance-python27/27/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-30 09:34:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@markwash

Yes, I see where you're coming from wrt decorator over-use significantly obscuring the underlying intent, as we see with the multiple decorators and method-nesting in the nova code you reference.

But in the current case I think the usage is simple enough to enhance the code clarity as opposed to detracting from it as in the nova example.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-30 09:47:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-30 15:27:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks, Eoghan. Two final thoughts here:

1) I'm not in love with 'mutating' as the name for this decorator, but I can't come up with a better alternative.

2) It's frustrating that the tests passed on patchset 3 without having that webob.exc import in there. I'm assuming something that imports that utils module had the appropriate import and that's a feature of python that we can't really control. 

+2"}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-30 19:14:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-30 19:17:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Wouldn't it be more readable and easier (and less methods needed to decorate) if we made the decorator @readonly and applied it to the get/index methods instead of @mutating being applied to all non-read methods?"}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-30 19:20:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not merge

Good call, Jay. I like that approach.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-30 19:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Jay,
I'm a bit confused about how your alternate proposal would work. Just imagining, it seems to me that we have to figure out a way to raise an exception on mutating functions, and not on readonly functions. And I can't figure out a way to do that while only modifying the readonly functions.

Maybe its just a lack of imagination on my part, but can you help me out?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-30 20:35:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Jay,

Interesting suggestion, but like Mark I'm confused as to how it would work in practice.

The action required in the @readonly case is a no-op, so the decorator would be completely passive. But we'd still need something check the context and raise the 403 if necessary in the mutating case.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-30 20:56:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Doh, yeah, Eoghan and Mark, you're completely correct..."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-30 20:57:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The only other suggestion I might have would be to rename @mutating to @noreadonly?'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-31 09:16:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-31 09:25:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

commit_message:
Add read-only enforcement to v2 API.

Provide a new @mutating decorator to provide a concise marker for
operations that should not be accessible to a read-only request.

Related to bp api-v2-anonymous-access

Change-Id: I52710083b4f112d2429afe4faa0660e2a6822929

commit_message:
README.rst: use correct Ubuntu/Debian package names for Maven

In the official Ubuntu and Debian package repos, there's no "maven3"
package. The Maven 3 package is just named "maven", and its predecessor
is "maven2". Fix up package names.

Change-Id: I95384a4eb7252fc62ebd7b3ada9f491b7386259b

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2861, 'name': 'Vincent Hou', 'email': 'shou@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'houshengbo'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:18:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

In addition to the highlighted PEP8 errors, you will also need to add yourself to Authors.  Please make sure you run the PEP8 tests to verify you got all the PEP8 problems‚Ä¶'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2012-05-08 16:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2012-05-08 16:26:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-08 16:45:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-05-08 17:05:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If making previously nullable columns non-nullable, then don't you need to fill in default data for any fields that are null?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-08 18:35:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

(1 inline comment)

OK, it seems you missed some PEP8 errors.  You really should run the test suite to find all errors (including PEP8 and hacking-compliance errors) prior to pushing a patch set up for review‚Ä¶'}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2012-05-09 02:19:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-09 15:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-05-09 23:15:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Vincent, can you please respond to my original question?"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-05-11 16:39:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Devin, actually, no you possibly don't. I'm not sure if there are constraints you can add, but MySQL at least will allow you to convert a column to non null. It will throw warnings in the process, however.

While it seems to be technically correct, I'm think I agree with Devin that it's probably an ugly thing to do. Tentative -1"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-05-11 16:40:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Devin: what I meant to say is that it will allow you to convert a column with NULL values to a non-null column. It appears to insert a blank value (possibly the empty string, you can see how little I know about the guts of mysql)'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-05-13 21:07:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Matt: Yep, that's why I'm sticking with a -1 here.  The data should be explicitly populated with reasonable defaults here."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:51:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

agree with dietz, +1 to explicit"}, {'account_id': 2861, 'date': '2012-05-24 02:52:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Well, I just added nullable=False when it is necessary.

For example, in models.py
1.target_num and host in IscsiTarget, reason: there is already a unique constraint __table_args__ = (schema.UniqueConstraint("target_num", "host") for them.
vpn_public_address and vpn_public_port in Network, there is a unique constraint __table_args__ = (schema.UniqueConstraint("vpn_public_address","vpn_public_port") for them.

2. In 082_essex.py, from top to bottom:
Column host in aggregate_hosts is already defined unique. Is it possible for it to be null?
Column name in aggregates is already defined unique. Is it possible for it to be null?
Column UUID in auth_tokens. Is it possible for it to be null?
Column in virtual_interfaces is already defined unique. Is it possible for it to be null?

The reason why I add the constraints is that when I test with other sqlalchemy-supporting databases, the creation won't succeed if the strict constraints are not added. This works well in mysql, because mysql has a certain tolerance for non-strict constraints. 

I think nova should at least take them into account. Or anyone else has other solutions?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-31 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-31 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

subject: Bug 890411: service roles and ID filtering
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 6, 'name': 'Joe Heck', 'email': 'heckj@mac.com', 'username': 'heckj'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 154, 'name': 'Liem Nguyen', 'email': 'liem.m.nguyen@hp.com', 'username': 'liemmn'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 494, 'name': 'termie', 'email': 'termie@openstack.org', 'username': 'termie'}, {'_account_id': 1091, 'name': 'Arun Kant', 'email': 'arukant@cisco.com', 'username': 'arunkant-uws'}, {'_account_id': 1916, 'name': 'Guang Yee', 'email': 'gyee@suse.com', 'username': 'guang-yee'}, {'_account_id': 1941, 'name': 'Lin Hua Cheng', 'email': 'os.lcheng@gmail.com', 'username': 'lin-hua-cheng'}, {'_account_id': 2106, 'name': 'Jason Rouault', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:32:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

code generally looks good - but I need to read it further. This change should include changes to the documentation to explain the expansion of role as applied to a service, because with the current implementation role is only in relation to a user & tenant, and is agnostic of service."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-02 15:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Where do I submit the document? The concept of service role was there prior to KSL. Otherwise, user with "Admin" role name can be admins for all services. That's a security vulnerability.

Without this feature, we are pretty much limited to role name taxonomy. i.e. "nova:Admin", "swift:Admin",etc. Which would required services to consistently parse role names to avoid security vulnerability with name conflicts.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-05-02 19:27:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Guang - 

there's documentation in the form of restructured text under doc/source/ - under there, minimally update architecture.rst, and configuration.rst and/or configuringservices.rst for how it relates to your changes. It may be reasonable to expand the docs from where they are today to explain the changes and how they can be used in an implementation."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-03 03:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:50:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Commit message needs to be cleaned up -- only the last change ID should be kept"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:51:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

First line of commit message should also explain what this change is in 50 chars or less'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-03 15:58:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-03 16:28:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:11:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(9 inline comments)

Only reviewed a bit of the docs, but the RST needs some work."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-03 17:12:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

You might want to read http://docutils.sourceforge.net/rst.html'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-05-03 19:39:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not submit

while being able to prevent the creation of roles that would be meaningful to another service is a goal, the implementation of that prevention seems more correctly placed in the policy codebase.

A quick example of a simple implementation would be to say something like:

 * to create/associate a role that starts with "service:" one needs to have the "keystone:admin" role
 * to create/associate a role that starts with "compute:" one needs to have the "service:compute" role

this would prevent roles from being assigned by services without proper permissions and allow the full flexibility of the policy engine to be applied'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-03 20:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Guys, thanks for the review.

Dolph, I'll sure I run "make html" this time and double check on the format.

Termie, we went over this argument already. See Bug 890411. This patch does NOT preclude others from continue to doing the naming hack. It simply offers, in our opinion, a better alternative. 

As I mentioned in the previous comment, the concept of service role was there prior to KSL. Without this feature, we are pretty much limited to role name taxonomy. i.e. "nova:Admin", "swift:Admin",etc. Which would required services to consistently parse role names to avoid security vulnerability with name conflicts.'}, {'account_id': 154, 'date': '2012-05-03 20:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Most of all, this fixes a security hole in Keystone Essex.  With Folsom RBAC, this may become irrelevant; but, we need it for Essex.'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-05-03 20:58:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

this is not a solution we want, it adds significantly more code and concept than a different solution

as for fixing a security hole, the "hole" it fixes is that a service with admin rights can set roles for other services, however

1) they have admin access, there is no finer grained access in essex, because:
2) in essex all services must be trusted anyway as the token used for authentication is easily re-used by an untrusted service to impersonate any user'}, {'account_id': 2106, 'date': '2012-05-03 21:11:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The issue this fixes is preventing someone with the Swift Admin role having 'Admin' access in Nova for the same given tenant.  This has nothing to do about role creation."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-03 21:33:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The amount of code is irrelevant here unless Keystone have requirement on the footprint.

Trusted services is also orthogonal to this solution. That's a whole new can of worms we need to deal with. At the moment, all services are assumed to be implicitly trusted.

As Jason mentioned, this solution precisely address the vulnerability with role leaks."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-04 04:07:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-04 04:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

This patch includes the rst cleanup. I ran "make html" and made sure the generated htmls look OK.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-04 13:05:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(9 inline comments)

Code looks good overall. Few little doc nits inline..."}, {'account_id': 154, 'date': '2012-05-04 15:45:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-04 18:20:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(32 inline comments)

Lots of doc tweaks"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-04 18:28:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Generally speaking, I don't want to invent new terminology: "service roles."

If every instance of that phrase simply read "service-specific roles," I think that would be self-explanatory enough to avoid expanding keystone's concept glossary.

Also, I haven't reviewed anything beyond docs yet.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-05 00:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (5 inline comments)

Rolling another patch with the recommended doc changes.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-05 00:30:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2012-05-08 01:06:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Code looks good to me, this provides the flexibility to control security of services within the tenant.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-08 20:47:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good stuff, thx for those fixups, Guang. :)'}, {'account_id': 154, 'date': '2012-05-14 21:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good, Guang. Just fix the smoketest failure and I think we are good.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-16 17:12:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-16 17:14:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

This patch should take care of the SmokeStack failures. I've tested it with MySQL as well."}, {'account_id': 154, 'date': '2012-05-16 17:52:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks for fixing the Smokestack failure'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-17 14:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Please ignore the SmokeStack failure above...

There is a bad prettytable in PyPi causing this:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1000757'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

testing'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-21 21:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Restored'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-22 21:37:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: (4 inline comments)

Spent just a couple minutes reviewing docs... few minor suggestions, and had a question inline.

In general, I'm a little wary of this landing around the time v3 is finalized (with a long term RBAC approach being a significant change in v3, potentially solving the same issues addressed here). If the use case is different than the direction of RBAC in v3, please speak up!"}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2012-05-23 04:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-23 13:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I just added some comments to the V3 API draft concerning role-action-endpoint mapping that I think solves the use case being addressed here; feedback appreciated.'}, {'account_id': 1091, 'date': '2012-05-24 05:43:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Changes looks good.

Will be good to have some test around service id filter for validate token call.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2012-05-24 05:54:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Dolph, thanks for taking a look. I've provided my feedbacks for the V3 API draft. I am still not quite understand how RBAC solves the role name conflict problem. Yes, a role can map to different capabilities for different service endpoints. But this patch specifically address the problem with role name distinctions. i.e. how can we tell a role with role name "Admin" is really the admin for Nova, not Swift or others.

The are two approaches to solve this problem, both are documented in the bug. One is to append the service name to the role name. For example, 'nova:Admin'. The other is to explicit tight the role to a service. There are drawback to the former.

1) there's no explicit check on the role name. For example, if there's a typo on the role name, say 'nove:Admin" instead of 'nova:Admin', Keystone wouldn't be able to easily prevent  that. On the other hand, if role is explicitly tight to a service (i.e. by making service ID a foreign key), some backends such as SQL can implicitly check for that.
2) there's no way to filter roles by service
3) if there's ever a need to rename a service, we would have to update all the role names everywhere.
4) naming hack is often dangerous in the face of i18n

btw, this patch does not prevent users from continuing to do the naming hack as service ID filtering is completely optional.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-31 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-31 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Bug 890411: service roles and ID filtering

Re-introduce the changes back into the KSL branch so we have a way to mitigate
risks with tenant role conflicts.

1) re-implemented service roles that were there prior to KSL
2) re-introduced service ID filtering for token validation

Change-Id: Ice41fb2ee9ec218d8adac5b5db8a1621b2efffd6

commit_message:
Move queue_get_for() from db to rpc.

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

The function queue_get_for() is a utility function used by various
consumers of the rpc API.  This function lived in the db API, but never
ended up using anything from the database.  This patch moves it into the
rpc API so that it can be used by other users of rpc once it moves into
openstack-common.

Change-Id: If92675beecff5471b416a929c161b810e3c71939

Having trusted_client.py and trusted_attest.py in the filters directory is a little misleading since they aren't actually filters."}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2012-05-16 16:27:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-16 18:15:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is solid code, with a long history of going back and forth with reviews.  While there isn't a specific need for these filters to live inside of nova, I don't mind it going in.  It seems like a fairly easy chunk to not break.  If these filters need to be updated frequently though, I'm going to recommend that they be pulled back out and shipped along with the open attestation code.

I also would like some other members of nova core to comment on this before I +2."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-05-16 18:19:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-05-16 18:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

My only remaining comment is there is no reference on how to make a compute node report to the attestation server, but that is fine by me as it is out of the scope of OpenStack.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-21 17:21:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

Don, code looks very good!

Some small nits inline, but the major problem I see is that the trusted client needs to be monkey-patched for eventlet... see more details inline.

best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2012-05-22 20:11:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-22 23:19:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(30 inline comments)

This is actually a massive improvement over I871702ad91fbe83ba5c76dab95b4dd163662797b

I don't have any fundamental issues with merging this patch - all of my comments are cleanup suggestions

The only fundamental issue I see is noted inline:

  The obvious problem here is that we're polling the 
  attestation service for each host individually when 
  scheduling an instance. This is an obvious scaling issue.

  However, I think you're taking a reasonably pragmatic 
  approach here - the caching of host states was a problem 
  with the previous patch, so you're punting this as an 
  optimization detail for later. Fair enough IMHO

Nice work Don"}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2012-05-23 18:27:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Mark- Tnx for the review, I'll incorporate most of your suggestions but I do have a few questions:

1)  trusted_attest.py:164 - I'd like to leave the capability to ask the attestation service about multiple hosts in the code.  This could become an opttimization capability in the future (for example, the first time a node is scheduled it's added to a list and future requests ask the attestation service about all hosts on the list, on the assumption that the candidate hosts will typically be the same set for most scheduling requests).

2)  test_host_filters.py - I agree the test coverage is not 100% but I need some pointers on how to do better.  The issue is to test the actual client/attest code you have to make an HTTPS connection to an attestation server.  How do you fake something like that in the test harness?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-23 19:08:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Don:

1) The code can easily be added in the future when it's needed. I really don't like adding unused or overly complex code for a future which may never come to pass.

2) You can use the stubout module to have BaseClient.get_connection() return a fake object. Here's an example:

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/9462474c143a88914997206b2179f6020b8cb095/glance/tests/unit/test_http_store.py#L35"}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2012-05-23 21:51:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

OK, I think I only have one final (?) issue:

3)  The trusted-computing-pools blueprint is immutable so I can't modify it to match the slight change in the actual implemetation.  What's the best way to resolve this?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-05-24 07:10:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

The "full specification" on the wiki isn't immutable, is it? That's what I was looking at'}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2012-05-24 15:22:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-09 02:31:56.000000000', 'message': "Add Trusted Computing Pool support

[V2 - re-format to remove tabs]

Implements blueprint trusted-computing-pools

Add a scheduling filter that filters based upon the trustedness of
a node.  A request is sent to the attestation service to disover the
trustedness of the target node and, only if it matches the `trust' key/value
pair in the `extra_specs' for the instance type, then the instance
can be started on that node.

To setup an attestation server go to the Open Attestation Project at:

        https://github.com/OpenAttestation/OpenAttestation

Also add tests for the new filter that checks the three conditions:

1)  Schedule works with no trust in the extra specs
2)  Schedule works with correct trust value in the extra specs
3)  Schedule fails will incorrect trust value in the extra specs

Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Fred Yang <fred.yang@intel.com>

Change-Id: Iafa6aed8061f6cd4630367553aee14bd4b0263e2

"}, {'created': '2012-05-29 03:51:06.000000000', 'message': "Add scheduler filter for trustedness of a host

Implements blueprint trusted-computing-pools

Add a scheduling filter that filters based upon the trustedness of
a node.  A request is sent to the attestation service to disover the
trustedness of the target node and, only if it matches the `trust_host'
key/value pair in the `extra_specs' for the instance type, then the
instance can be started on that node.  More details can be found in the
docspec for the filter in:

	nova/scheduler/filters/trusted_filter.py

To setup an attestation server go to the Open Attestation Project at:

        https://github.com/OpenAttestation/OpenAttestation

Also add 5 tests for the new filter that verifies:

1)  Schedule works with no trust in the extra specs
2)  Schedule works with trusted instance and trusted host
3)  Schedule works with untrusted instance and untrusted host
4)  Schedule fails with trusted instance and untrusted host
5)  Scheduel fails with untrusted instance and trusted host

Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Fred Yang <fred.yang@intel.com>

Change-Id: Iafa6aed8061f6cd4630367553aee14bd4b0263e2

commit_message:
Add scheduler filter for trustedness of a host

Implements blueprint trusted-computing-pools

Add a scheduling filter that filters based upon the trustedness of
a node.  A request is sent to the attestation service to disover the
trustedness of the target node and, only if it matches the `trust_host'
key/value pair in the `extra_specs' for the instance type, then the
instance can be started on that node.  More details can be found in the
docspec for the filter in:

	nova/scheduler/filters/trusted_filter.py

To setup an attestation server go to the Open Attestation Project at:

        https://github.com/OpenAttestation/OpenAttestation

Also add 5 tests for the new filter that verifies:

1)  Schedule works with no trust in the extra specs
2)  Schedule works with trusted instance and trusted host
3)  Schedule works with untrusted instance and untrusted host
4)  Schedule fails with trusted instance and untrusted host
5)  Scheduel fails with untrusted instance and trusted host

Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Fred Yang <fred.yang@intel.com>

Change-Id: Iafa6aed8061f6cd4630367553aee14bd4b0263e2

commit_message:
Sample config file tool updates

Fixes bug #1000133

Current method of extracting config options will not work
once the global config object gets removed.

1. Update tool to read a cfg.Opt subclass instance or list of cfg.Opt subclass
   instances rather than the FLAG object.
2. Word wrap help messages
3. Insert line between consecutive options
4. Print warnings for missing option help string

Change-Id: Idd17048b6e8db6e939946968e011e68da8585b8c

[{'created': '2012-05-23 19:36:43.000000000', 'message': 'Record instance architecture types.

In order to support image architectures other than x86,
we need to record the instance architecture when it is running.

Glance has the information that we need so we take the
information that glance provides us.

This is the first step for support other arches like armhf.

commit_message:
Record instance architecture types.

In order to support image architectures other than x86,
we need to record the instance architecture when it is running.

Glance has the information that we need so we take the
information that glance provides us.

This is the first step for support other arches like armhf.

Change-Id: Ia9ca1353a7cf56955d00d17f7bc1bfb3712a89ab
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Fix topics so that the do not collide with nova.

 * Without this, there are issues running cinder if
   you have previously run n-vol
 * Fix pep8

Change-Id: Id56dbfd6c4f62a74cc57edcc7859753dd7e36229

commit_message:
Use cfg's new global CONF object

Implements blueprint cfg-global-object

Replace nova.flags.FLAGS with openstack.common.cfg.CONF.

In future, we can do a s/FLAGS/CONF/ across the codebase.

Change-Id: Ib293873089a5399febd7a3b0410f66e9bef115f1

commit_message:
fixing issue with db.volume_update not returning the volume_ref

fixes bug #1003664

- changed the sqlalchemy db api code to return the volume_ref from the
volume_update method. This was causing the volume  notifications to
have the incorrect information in the payload.
- Fixed up the unit tests because they started failing badly.
- fixed the volume-usage-audit reading the default config values
- fix hacking issue with volume-usage-audit

Change-Id: Iba5634b0c351a6cc0c48b697217a6f85533de93e

commit_message:
Added help text in local.settings.example
how to setup Horizon to use SSL-offloading proxy
to properly handle page redirects to SSL.

The example is for Django 1.4 only.
As I see at the moment Django 1.3 is
not supported (pip-requires says Django>=1.4),
so no example for Django 1.3 is added.

Fixes bug 999960

Change-Id: I3b885e84ef8332bfd0fe35a2307eb691cf34be03

subject: Revert "API users should not see deleted flavors."
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 159, 'name': 'Eric Windisch', 'email': 'ewindisch@docker.com', 'username': 'ewindisch'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 693, 'name': 'Christopher MacGown', 'email': 'chris@pistoncloud.com', 'username': '0x44'}, {'_account_id': 927, 'name': 'Gabe Westmaas', 'email': 'gabe.westmaas@rackspace.com', 'username': 'westmaas'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:53:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

(1 inline comment)

Hey Josh,

I did this revert.... rather than keep reverting things on each other why don't we agree on how this should work?

---

Couple of things:

1) This query isn't just exposed for admin's. It is exposed for all users via the /flavors controller.

2) We really should have a test case for this since changing it back and forth doesn't break anything.

3) This commit breaks Tempest. If we are gonna change it I'd like to see us change Tempest first."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:57:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-29 21:57:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-pep8/54/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-merge/54/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python27/56/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python26/55/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-05-29 22:08:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think users can see deleted images right now, either.  We need to figure out the desired behavior and make both behave the same way, I think.  I don't think deleted images and flavors should show up in a 'list'.  However, I do think there should be some sort of way for a user to query a deleted image/instance_type if they have a reference to it somehow.  (Maybe if we keep copies of the data w/ the instance... the information can be returned when you do a detailed GET of the instance.  We already have a way to do this for image properties as we are storing copies as instance_system_metadata.  See below.)

I think we're going to need to start storing instance_type information with instances as instance_system_metadata like we do for image properties.  I think we run into code problems if an old instance_type is deleted right now.. .and you try to do things like resize and rebuild..  because I think we base some decisions based on the old instance type information.

Ie, I think we have other bugs right now if an in-use instance_type is deleted.

If we can copy the instance_type information into instance_system_metadata associated with an instance... we could easily return this information to a user on a detailed instance GET.  But, I think that would require an API change."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-29 22:12:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-29 22:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-pep8/55/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-merge/55/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python27/57/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/check-nova-python26/56/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-29 23:49:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Uhm, what does the API spec say? That's what Tempest's failing test was written to, which is why the original change was reverted..."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-05-30 02:45:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Jay, as written the spec breaks the API server if a VM instance is built against a deleted flavor. It doesn't seem reasonable to be able to delete something that is referenced, but at the same time it doesn't seem reasonable to delete all existing VMs because an operator wants to prevent new VMs from being built with that flavor."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-30 13:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Still not a fan of this.

More thoughts:

If we are allowing users to "see" deleted flavors why aren't we doing the same thing for images as well? Seems like the same issues would occur there.

---

Also, if a user can see a deleted flavor does that mean they can continue to use it as well. This seems like it could be an unintended side effect.

---

Wasn't the original use case motivating this fix due to an issue in Horizon where deleting a flavor caused some UI errors. It seems Horizon could cache flavors to avoid these types of errors.'}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2012-05-30 13:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Not sure if this is the best place to continue this discussion, but here goes:

No matter what, we are broken right now, and we need to fix this.  I think it makes sense to allow users to be able to see deleted objects (flavors, images, instances) as long as there is a way to see whether or not it is deleted (I don't believe the flavors objects have a deleted status).  After all, you can already do this in a roundabout way by making calls with a "changes-since" parameter.  When attempting to build an instance from a deleted image or flavor, the build should absolutely fail.

What changes need to be made to the API spec to accomodate this and still get this fixed?  Does this change prevent building from a deleted flavor, as Dan asked?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-30 14:46:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Gabe:

Wow. I suppose I always thought objects marked as "deleted" could be purged from the database in a a suitable off hours timeframe (to minimize beating up the DB during the day).

I didn't realize Nova, Glance, etc were under contract to maintain deleted records until all potential references to them are deleted in the system.

If subsystems need to keep track of flavors and/or images I suppose I always figured it best to have those systems cache their own data?'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-05-30 15:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

FWIW, builds do fail when trying to boot from a deleted instance type.'}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2012-05-30 15:21:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think it comes down to balancing what a customer would want, and what a provider is willing to provide.  However, I think I may need to clarify a little:

Nova should never fail to show an existing instance even if a flavor has been completely purged, or an image has been deleted permanently (removed from the glance db).  

I don't think there should be any contract on keeping an image, flavor, or instance for a given length of time after it has been deleted.  Alternatively, if this makes the suggestion below useless, how long it is available should be both configurable and queryable. 

I do think a customer should be able to get metadata about a flavor, image or instance even if it has been deleted for as long as the provider is willing to keep that information.  I wonder if we need to provide a parameter (similar to changes-since) that would allow an API user to see a deleted object when they want to."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-30 19:34:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Chris, Gabe, others, I wasn't trying to get into a pissing match about what the customer would expect. All I was saying is that the spec says one thing and that's what the tempest test is looking for. Either we need to change the spec or change the implemntation. If the spec is changed, then we'll update the tempest test, simple as that. :)"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-30 20:11:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

API users shouldn't see those deleted flavors by default, but we do need to be able to delete flavors without destroying the instances that are using those flavors. Thus, it does stand to reason that we should be able to explicitly query those flavors and provide metadata on them, even if they do not appear on a general 'list' request."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-30 20:23:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks for the test case and comment updates Josh.

Okay. So I did a bit more digging...

We already have this behavior for images...

[root@nova1 ~]# nova image-show 596f4118-f787-4dea-bcf9-86865d8f163d
+----------+--------------------------------------+
| Property |                Value                 |
+----------+--------------------------------------+
| created  | 2012-05-30T13:35:47Z                 |
| id       | 596f4118-f787-4dea-bcf9-86865d8f163d |
| minDisk  | 0                                    |
| minRam   | 0                                    |
| name     | ami-tty                              |
| progress | 0                                    |
| status   | DELETED                              |
| updated  | 2012-05-30T20:15:20Z                 |
+----------+--------------------------------------+

And the API SPECS for /images and /flavors are pretty much identical with regards to a detailed GET request. So I'm not sure a SPEC update is required for this.

We are going to have to change one of the Tempest tests with regard to flavors. (I can do that if you want)

I think I'm coming around to this now."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-30 20:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Dan, no worries, just let me know what needs to change in the tempest test and I can take care of it.

All the best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-05-30 21:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Okay. Here is the Tempest change needed for this:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7932/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-30 22:26:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4423/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/242/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/240/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2640/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4044/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-30 22:26:32.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Revert "API users should not see deleted flavors."

This reverts commit f6e62c6120453fa90e2e690753fe6eaf157f2dde. We
need to be able to query deleted flavors for instances that may
be running on deleted flavors.

Change-Id: I9ae80c525c9bc1e3172bd4e7ffe50fe74f2d3a51

commit_message:
Fix the conf argument to get_connection_pool().

The first argument to amqp.get_connection_pool() should be a global
config object, not the Connection.

Change-Id: Ic0b8f32ea42bdebdd883175a1351b3a52f26942d

Deleted flavors can be viewed ... but not listed.

Updates the test_get_flavor_details_for_deleted_flavor test
case so that deleted flavors can be viewed but not listed.

commit_message:
Make xenapi fake match real xenapi a bit closer

xenstore_data is a dictionary in the real xenapi and keys get deleted
from xenstore_data and other_config when removing them instead of being
set to None.

Change-Id: I462b04b6e1dc5ad4abf05cc50538121811c2334e

commit_message:
Add attach_time for EC2 Volumes

According to the EC2 API spec, attach_time has a
timestamp that is returned when running euca-describe-volumes.
Openstack EC2 API currently does not do this.

This fixes bug 1001828

Change-Id: I571b937481f22e8d0f4eb38d4cabcafc5fbb920b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

Actually ... the new fanout test could be a problem for impl_kombu.  See this in nova/tests/rpc/test_kombu.py:

    @test.skip_test("kombu memory transport seems buggy with fanout queues "
            "as this test passes when you use rabbit (fake_rabbit=False)")
    def test_fanout_send_receive(self):


So I'm afraid of this new test randomly failing for kombu.  Maybe we should force this new fanout test to be skipped for kombu?

Chris, any thoughts on this?'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-26 03:39:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Russell: I saw this too, but I've run this test against kombu in-memory quite a few times and it hasn't failed yet."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-05-26 03:48:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'd have to dig into a bit deeper, but the kombu mechanism is asynchronous. Perhaps the assertion is happening before the cast is consumed? It appears this way from the test, but the conn.consume(limit=1) and conn.close() might be guaranteeing the delivery?

I avoid this in my test by using the eventlet queue, which blocks."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-05-27 00:24:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

It doesn't look like it's async based on the way that test is written.  However, your new test is passing for me and is passing on smokestack, so I say we push it on through and we can disable it for kombu if it turns out to be a problem (but so far seems fine)."}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-05-29 14:33:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

New RPC tests, docstring fixes.

Also fixes versioning problem in impl_fake
Makes topics configurable by RPC test suites.

commit_message:
Remove nova.context dependency from nova.rpc

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

This patch removes the usage of nova.context from nova.rpc.  Everything
needed to implement RpcContext now exists within nova.rpc.

Change-Id: I9e6ec0d22e55d3d4f38e12e0fdd2df745da496f5

commit_message:
Remove nova.log usage from nova.rpc.

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

This patch removes the usage of nova.log from nova.rpc.  This is
necessary before nova.rpc can be moved to openstack-common.  The rpc
logging was not using any of the extra features provided in nova.log as
far as I can tell, so the changes are very simple.

This is the final dependency.  After this change, the rpc code
can be moved to openstack-common without any changes.

Change-Id: I17ca4b691bb8d4f18e618632a2381dd12d31852a

commit_message:
Set sql_connection in glance-api.conf

The v2 API uses the database directly from the glance-api server. We
need to provide the same connection credentials as we set for the
glance-registry server.

Change-Id: I5093a9f7978f627e1dee4047b1f45383f9e4e7da

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-25 16:27:43.000000000', 'message': "Fix reservation_commit so it works w/ PostgreSQL.

Updates the reservation_commit/reservation_rollback functions
in the SQLAlchmemy DB API so they work with PostgreSQL.
PostgreSQL doesn't support using 'SELECT FOR UPDATE' when
using table joins. This modifications makes two queries
to perform the same action.

Fixes LP Bug #1003756.

Change-Id: I3c40bd8481855a18391e12d7411762e91b1ef8b0
"}, {'created': '2012-05-30 16:41:21.000000000', 'message': "Fix reservation_commit so it works w/ PostgreSQL.

Update the Reservation model so that the 'usage' relationship is
explicitly forced to use an inner join. This fixes an issue on
PostgreSQL which doesn't support 'SELECT FOR UPDATE' on outer
joined queries.

Fixes LP Bug #1003756.

Change-Id: I3c40bd8481855a18391e12d7411762e91b1ef8b0
"}]
commit_message:
Fix reservation_commit so it works w/ PostgreSQL.

Update the Reservation model so that the 'usage' relationship is
explicitly forced to use an inner join. This fixes an issue on
PostgreSQL which doesn't support 'SELECT FOR UPDATE' on outer
joined queries.

Fixes LP Bug #1003756.

Change-Id: I3c40bd8481855a18391e12d7411762e91b1ef8b0

commit_message:
Remove the reference to non existing exception by linuxbridgeplugin.

Bug #1006221

According to plugin api of QuantumPluginBase, unplug_interface
should only raise exception.NetworkNotFound and exception.PortNotFound.
To unplug a non-attached port should not raise Exception.
After this modification, to unplug an non-attached port will have no impact.
In addition, I remove the 'network = db.network_get(net_id)' since
 'db.validate_port_ownership(tenant_id, net_id, port_id)' statement has taken
care of the check.

patch 2: split test case to test it exclusively compared to patch 1.
patch 3: remove added test statement in previous test case

commit_message:
Replace eucatools with references to nova CLI

fixes bug 891552

It has been decided to prefer novaclient over euca2ools when novaclient
does the job, so this fix is to bring the compute manual to implement
the remaining changes to bring it to fuitition.

Most of the work here is in the volumes section. Essentialy hacked
away to replace euca-*-volume commands with nova volume-*.

Also removed some old volumes-related text that seemed irrelevant in
current releases.

Cherry picked from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7608/

Change-Id: I020f86d337527c38af719703909ad52ae35f2d7b

commit_message:
Enable anonymous access through context middleware

Certain deployments need to allow anonymous access to its
images. This patch allows a user that has failed to authenticate with
Keystone to access the API in read-only context.

* Configure through 'allow_anonymous_access' option, defaults to False
* Implements bp api-v2-anonymous-access

Change-Id: Ia8f57e54bd141a2da1ca4600d1970558fb497f67

commit_message:
Expose tags on image entities in v2 API

Enable users to set and view tags on image entities. Before, a user
had to navigate to the /tags subcollection to interact with image tags.
Additionally, this refactors the image_tag_* methods to return strings
rather than sqlalchemy objects.

* Related to bp api-v2-image-tags

Change-Id: Ifdebe9b660f78bee5fda798a1f83e384a8220049

messages:
[{'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-05-04 08:51:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Can we get this backported please? It's a very insignificant patch which doesn't affect the users, but it makes things a lot easier when running automated testsuites."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-05-04 23:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Minor nitpick (comment inline).  Love the idea of a useful exit status for the test runners.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-05-07 08:01:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Darrell

I agree with you on the variable naming. But I don't know if it would be a good idea to change it in stable/essex while this patch already got accepted as is in master. It would get overwritten anyway. Or I'd have to submit another review request just to change the name of those variables which I don't think makes sense."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:15:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Good point... so never mind, it's better to be consistent with what was accepted into master."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-22 06:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-22 06:03:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-05-22 09:13:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Restored

I know this looks like a minor patch, but it's really useful for running automated tests."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-05-22 09:49:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I thought for testsuite tox would be used? but other than that this look good.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-22 14:54:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
make test runner functions return the status of running the tests

This makes it a lot easier for CI jobs to be setup and return the true
status of the testsuite.

Change-Id: I0c2b0d6b17f560a889cd2f22ab98a68361f6d738

subject: Implement image prefetching in a separate tool.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-11 05:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-05-11 09:16:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Some small comments"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-11 11:59:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-11 12:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-05-11 20:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Perhaps there is a more elegant way to handle the image prefetch then adding a binary that is designed to be run with sudo permissions as a cron job.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-12 00:40:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Joe -- I'm happy to talk about this. However, the request at the design summit was that this be a separate command line tool, instead of being a periodic task (or something like that), which was the original plan.

You object to new command line tools?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-05-16 17:40:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Michael -- My concern with a separate command line tool, is the nova/bin tools aren't covered by unit tests making it easy for the tools to code rot as Nova quickly evolves."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-22 22:02:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-30 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Implement image prefetching in a separate tool.

Optionally prefetch images for compute nodes using the new nova-node
command line tool. This review implements features described in
blueprint nova-image-cache-management-2.

Change-Id: I8a656f708f09d6cc0bdc66cd7e6e6919fed91d26

commit_message:
Parse linuxbridge plugins using openstack.common.cfg

Implements the blueprint use-common-cfg

In order for the linuxbridge plugin to use the rpc code soon to be merged into
openstack-common, we need to parse our configuration using cfg. Here we
make the most simple, backwards compatible change in that direction.

The same is relevant for the openvswitch implementation

Fixes after comments.

Change-Id: I70fc1898a802cb4198f72741453283d114added2

commit_message:
Make ovs Interface option set properly.

Multiple ovs-vsctl set Interface option call overrides the previous
settings and result in unexpected partial condition.

commit_message:
Sync with latest version of openstack.common.cfg

Changes since last sync:

 - make reset() clear defaults and overrides
 - automatically create option groups
 - allow options to be marked as required
 - use a list comprehension instead of map()

Change-Id: I20d8b2e7a1fa0080398eaa8e03b0b6d48e7c2a29

[{'created': '2012-05-29 23:02:28.000000000', 'message': 'Bug #1004584

When running ovs_quantum_agent in tunneling mode and a new tunnel_ip is added while
an agent is running the following exception below occurs. This causes the agent to
no longer function since it becomes caught in a loop.

ERROR:__main__:Main-loop Exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "ovs_quantum_agent.py", line 583, in daemon_loop
    self.manage_tunnels(tunnel_ips, old_tunnel_ips, db)
  File "ovs_quantum_agent.py", line 550, in manage_tunnels
    self.add_tun_br_flows_for_local_vlan(lv_obj)
AttributeError: 'OVSQuantumTunnelAgent' object has no attribute 'add_tun_br_flows_for_local_vlan'

Change-Id: Id03dc4a12a0114c8597cb90f4eabcdd3dc9b3f5c
'}]
commit_message:
Bug #1004584

When running ovs_quantum_agent in tunneling mode and a new tunnel_ip is added while
an agent is running the following exception below occurs. This causes the agent to
no longer function since it becomes caught in a loop.

ERROR:__main__:Main-loop Exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "ovs_quantum_agent.py", line 583, in daemon_loop
    self.manage_tunnels(tunnel_ips, old_tunnel_ips, db)
  File "ovs_quantum_agent.py", line 550, in manage_tunnels
    self.add_tun_br_flows_for_local_vlan(lv_obj)
AttributeError: 'OVSQuantumTunnelAgent' object has no attribute 'add_tun_br_flows_for_local_vlan'

Change-Id: Id03dc4a12a0114c8597cb90f4eabcdd3dc9b3f5c

subject: Lock pep8 at v1.1
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-05-24 14:37:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Did something added to pep8 prompt this change?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-24 14:40:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yep, we've been scrambling to handle the breaking changes that v1.1 introduces in other projects this morning. We really shouldn't need to deal with that, so the safest thing to do is lock our dependency on latest for now. commit_message:
Add ACL check using <tenant_id>:<user> format.

Fixes bug 999998.

Swift auth middleware uses a new format for expressing
a container ACL for a user: <tenant_name>:<user>. This
fix add supports for checking ACL using the old format
of <tenant_id>:<user>.

Change-Id: I44985b191afb174605c35041741056ae1e78fa77

commit_message:
Changed arguments in keystone CLI for consistency.

Changed --user to --user_id and --role to --role_id in the keystone client for
consistency. Need to update keystone calls here.

This change should be applied after [bug/994744 b7fe11c] in
python-keystoneclient.

Fixes bug 994744.

Change-Id: I234c1d46c0d92a6a00ebb25c5dfbba69cd46be52

commit_message:
Allow other middleware overriding authentication.

- Implements blueprint swift-middleware-add-overrides-feature.
- Let other middleware do authentication for certain request allow
  tempurl or formpost to temporary allow access for certain object and do
  the validation in there.

Change-Id: I4f5bcb5832f96ced2c6c10d565737ae894771690

commit_message:
Expose timestamps on image entities in v2 API

* Add created_at and updated_at to image entities
* Ignore these timestamps on create & update
* Related to bp api-2

Change-Id: Iff0345de891e928367227f1a46f05e28b95de298

commit_message:
First cut of Network client and positive tests.

Fixes bug 946675.
1. Created Network (Quantum ) client for Tempest.
2. Added positive tests for Quantum.
3. Addressed review comments.

Change-Id: If3e27d3aadc70fbf6db722b6ae554a1188fe56e8

subject: One 'ctrl-c' kills keystone.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 6, 'name': 'Joe Heck', 'email': 'heckj@mac.com', 'username': 'heckj'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 494, 'name': 'termie', 'email': 'termie@openstack.org', 'username': 'termie'}, {'_account_id': 1188, 'name': 'Rafael Dur√°n Casta√±eda', 'username': 'rafadurancastaneda'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-04 18:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Awesome! Question inline'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-05-04 21:12:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

i remember vish having a solution for this, but i thought it looked different... vish?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-05-07 21:16:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

in nova we start all servers in a greenthread and catch the keyboard interrupt in the mainthread. We use a global launcher object:

446     try:
447         _launcher.wait()
448     except KeyboardInterrupt:
449         _launcher.stop()

on keyboard interrupt we do the following:

122     def stop(self):
123         """Stop all services which are currently running.
124 
125         :returns: None
126 
127         """
128         for service in self._services:
129             service.kill()

I don't know if it is necessarily better, but it does work without needing to register a signal handler.'}, {'account_id': 1188, 'date': '2012-05-07 21:46:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Here there is no global launcher so,that solution is not applicable without refactoring the Server class [1] and I don't think that is needed. However it's also unclear to me if the signal approach has any disadvantage over the try/KeyboardInterrupt approach, so I will do further research about that.

Dolph comment replied inline.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/common/wsgi.py#L54"}, {'account_id': 1188, 'date': '2012-05-08 22:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1188, 'date': '2012-05-08 22:47:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

About the signal handler concerns: Python by default register signal.default_int_handler to 'SIGINT' (and it just raises KeyboardInterrupt) and thus replacing the handle doesn't suppose any other difference but the code inside the handler."}, {'account_id': 1188, 'date': '2012-05-15 11:36:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1188, 'date': '2012-05-15 11:38:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Rebased master.'}, {'account_id': 1188, 'date': '2012-05-15 12:08:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

If you don't like the signal handler the same result can be achieved moving code from signal handler to server run method [1], just replacing the 'pass'.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/common/wsgi.py#L85"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-16 18:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-05-29 19:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-29 19:24:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-pep8/1237/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-05-29 19:24:13.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-05-19 20:05:03.000000000', 'message': "Auto generate AUTHORS file for nova.

Fixes Bug #976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

.mailmap
  Fix mailmap entries inline with actual author name and
  email address in git.

* AUTHORS
  Remove this file.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* horizon/openstack/common/setup.py
* horizon/openstack/common/__init__.py
* horizon/openstack/__init__.py
  Add this library from openstack-common code base.

* openstack-common.conf
  Share code from openstack-common. Include setup module to copy using
  update.py script.

* setup.py
  Import the new method.
  Generate AUTHORS file before creating the package.

* horizon/tests/authors_test.py
  Remove this test case.

Change-Id: I1e14dfbd0014faf68920e082ab53e0361b7ec8c8

commit_message:
Auto generate AUTHORS file for horizon.

Fixes Bug #976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

.mailmap
  Fix mailmap entries inline with actual author name and
  email address in git.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file to the list.

* horizon/openstack/common/setup.py
  Add this library from openstack-common code base.

* setup.py
  Import the new method.
  Generate AUTHORS file before creating the package.

Change-Id: I1e14dfbd0014faf68920e082ab53e0361b7ec8c8

John, looks like the dependency is set reverse. In reality, 7600 is dependent on this one 7772. But it's set as 7772 dependent on 7600.

Do you have a clue how to fix this dependency rule in gerrit?"}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-05-24 23:39:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's controlled by the ordering of your commits in your git branch. Don't bother, though. I already submitted my own patch for this to Jenkins which should be merged shortly.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7775/"}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-05-24 23:41:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge; No score

You can abandon this one, Gabriel's should fix it...

To avoid this in the future, make sure you have a local branch based off of master for each review you have up, that way the histories for each individual review will align with master, instead of depending on each other."}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-05-29 18:03:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

This change is already committed ...'}]

commit_message:
Add ProjectTestingInterface to horizon.

Horizon is the last project that doesn't have support for the common
Project Testing Interface. This gets horizon up to speed with the
other bits, but shouldn't break any of the existing interfaces.

Change-Id: I464c3b10d9708a0b7b5ffd42c88cd3cf515ef6a7
